title: Rep. Troy E. Nehls Secures Federal Funding for Two Projects in TX-22
description:
“I’m proud to announce that through the Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, which President Trump signed into law on November 12, I secured over $2.2 million in federal funding for two of my Community Project Funding requests, which will directly benefit communities in Texas’s 22nd Congressional District,” said Congressman Nehls.
"In the aftermath, the county, state, and local community volunteers did an outstanding job providing and distributing vital recovery items like ice, water, and food.
The community also lacked a facility to house FEMA personnel, so they had to station them 30 miles away.
These funds are crucial for ensuring the facilities to ease public suffering in this community following the next disaster.
I would like to thank Congressman Nehls and his staff for listening and acting to provide funds for this important project in the community of Sargent."
text:
WASHINGTON, D.C. —Congressman Troy E. Nehls (R-TX-22) is pleased to announce that over $2.2 million in federal funding has been secured for two projects in Texas’s 22nd Congressional District, including $1,875,000 for the construction of a community center in Sargent, Texas, which will serve as a Point of Distribution (POD) following a hurricane or other natural disaster, and over $346,000 to repair and upgrade the Wharton Dobson Club and Wharton Teen Scene Club in Wharton, Texas.

“I’m proud to announce that through the Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, which President Trump signed into law on November 12, I secured over $2.2 million in federal funding for two of my Community Project Funding requests, which will directly benefit communities in Texas’s 22nd Congressional District,” said Congressman Nehls. “From funds to construct a community center in Sargent, Texas, that will provide critical resources following natural disasters, to much-needed updates to the Wharton Dobson Club and Wharton Teen Scene Club, to provide a safe environment for children to learn and grow, these investments will have lasting positive effects on these communities for years to come.”

"On behalf of Matagorda County, I want to thank Congressman Nehls and his staff for their continued dedication and efforts to secure federal funding for a Point of Distribution(POD) in Matagorda County,” said Matagorda County Judge Bobby Seiferman. "The POD will be a welcome asset resource for emergency management in providing life-sustaining commodities after a disaster.”

"The community of Sargent, Texas, took the worst of Hurricane Beryl,” said Mike Estlinbaum, Matagorda County Commissioner for Precinct 2. "In the aftermath, the county, state, and local community volunteers did an outstanding job providing and distributing vital recovery items like ice, water, and food. What was found lacking was a location and infrastructure for the operation. The community also lacked a facility to house FEMA personnel, so they had to station them 30 miles away. These funds are crucial for ensuring the facilities to ease public suffering in this community following the next disaster. I would like to thank Congressman Nehls and his staff for listening and acting to provide funds for this important project in the community of Sargent."

name: Congress
title: Preserving Earth's last sanctuaries: A call for urgent action on primary forests - IUCN
description:
Primary forests are the heart of the global climate and biodiversity agenda, underpinning key international agreements such as the Paris Agreement and the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework.
Over 80 percent of terrestrial biodiversity lives in forests, and primary forests host the highest concentrations of species: especially those that are endemic, endangered or both.
Since 2001, the world has lost at least 83 million hectares of tropical primary forest and 50 million hectares of intact boreal forest.
A fundamental shift is needed in both policy and finance frameworks concerned with forest ecosystem integrity which sustains primary forests.
Protecting primary forests is not just an environmental imperative — it is a strategic policy decision with climate, economic and social benefits.
text:
Primary forests are the heart of the global climate and biodiversity agenda, underpinning key international agreements such as the Paris Agreement and the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework. These forests store dense carbon stocks while continuing to act as powerful carbon sinks. They also regulate water systems, reduce the risk of zoonotic disease, support livelihoods with essential resources, and provide irreplaceable habitat for countless species — many of them critically endangered and found nowhere else. Over 80 percent of terrestrial biodiversity lives in forests, and primary forests host the highest concentrations of species: especially those that are endemic, endangered or both. Primary forests fulfil a host of ecological functions, and the loss of these ecosystems is permanent — no restoration plan can replicate the complexity and resilience of intact forest landscapes within a reasonable timeframe, if ever.

Since 2001, the world has lost at least 83 million hectares of tropical primary forest and 50 million hectares of intact boreal forest. In 2024 alone, tropical primary forest loss exceeded 6.7 million hectares, releasing more than 3.1 gigatonnes of CO into the atmosphere — slightly more than India’s fossil fuel emissions that year. This marks a doubling of loss from 2023 and the highest annual rate in two decades — an alarming reversal of hard-won progress. Despite rising awareness, much of the global response remains misaligned and siloed. Although restoration efforts are extremely important to repairing functionality and restoring habitat in degraded areas and ought to be continually funded, these efforts should not be at the expense of preventing further deforestation and degradation of the primary forests that remain.

We cannot plant our way out of deforestation: prevention is more effective, more cost-efficient and ecologically far superior.

A fundamental shift is needed in both policy and finance frameworks concerned with forest ecosystem integrity which sustains primary forests. The Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), through the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework (GBF), aims to protect 30% of the planet by 2030, and countries are striving to make progress towards this target. Fortunately, the CBD took critical steps both in Montreal and in Cali to integrate a clear and strong ecosystem integrity mandate into the GBF in Goal A, and Targets 1, 2, 8 and 12. Of course, the comprehensive focus on ecosystem integrity in the GBF by definition includes primary forests, but it is important to recognise this explicitly in the CBD at COP 17. The financial commitments made through CBD by countries earlier this year represent a critical milestone, but unless primary forests are explicitly prioritised in national strategies, we are sadly liable to continue seeing significant deforestation and degradation, as was the case in 2024. Similarly, the financial commitments made at UNFCCC COP29 represent an important step towards accelerating action to combat climate change — but primary forest conservation remains an overlooked solution within climate dialogues.

Where primary forests remain, governments must integrate primary forest protection into their international commitments and back those promises with legally binding safeguards, robust monitoring, enforceable protections, policy coherence and elimination of harmful incentives. In parallel, global finance must evolve. Current funding models fall short in prioritising conservation efforts with the highest ecological returns — leaving primary forests underfunded and exposing biodiversity, climate and communities to avoidable harm.

Beyond just a new policy, safeguarding primary forests demands an evolution of mindset: environmental protection isn’t a barrier to economic growth — it’s a value-add, a long-term investment in resilience, stability and prosperity of the planet.

These ecosystems are not liabilities to be cleared or degraded for development — they are assets, already delivering high-value ecological services that underpin healthy societies and healthy economies.

Innovative financial mechanisms can help close this gap. Redirecting climate finance toward avoided deforestation strategies, including payments to communities for ecosystem services and sovereign debt swaps for countries which steadfastly protect their primary forests, can unlock substantial resources to maintain and restore the ecosystem integrity of forests. Nations and communities demonstrating effective forest stewardship should be directly rewarded. Moreover, Indigenous Peoples and local communities who have stewarded these landscapes for generations offer robust networks and approaches for maintaining these landscapes, a fact which has been reinforced by decisions made at CBD COP16 last year. Their governance systems have proven effective at protecting primary forests for millennia, and they are to this day both dependents and stewards of these ecosystems. Securing Indigenous land rights and channelling direct financial support to Indigenous forest stewards is not only equitable — it is a proven conservation strategy.

Some global conservation initiatives are already pushing for these changes and are backed by funding from multilateral organisations. For example, the Global Environment Facility (GEF), which provides the largest funding for forest protection globally, supports the conservation of tropical primary forests as a priority globally - -notably through the Amazon, Congo and Other Critical Forest Biomes Integrated Program, endowed with $306 million grants leveraging in addition around $1.5 billion, as well as through other global projects executed by IUCN, Wild Heritage, Griffith University and other pioneering partners. These initiatives demonstrate that investing in primary forest integrity can simultaneously advance benefits for climate, biodiversity, people and economies, creating a win-win situation for everyone.

Protecting primary forests is not just an environmental imperative — it is a strategic policy decision with climate, economic and social benefits. Yet without immediate intervention, these ecosystems will continue to disappear, weakening global efforts to combat climate change and stem accelerating biodiversity loss. Policymakers must act to close policy gaps, realign and unlock financial flows, and position primary forests as foundational to global sustainability

The time for action is now. The destruction of these ecosystems is irreversible.

name: American Energy
title: President Trump Wants to Drive America Into a Golden Age. South Dakota Can Help.
description:
At the same time, these large-load data centers will pay a greater share of the utilities’ fixed costs.
In those data centers, some of the water would evaporate into the skies above South Dakota, just like an irrigated cornfield, reservoir or golf course.
Being the state with the most data centers in the country, it performed a state audit that found that the data centers using water do so in a sustainable and well-regulated manner.
35 states–including South Dakota’s neighbors North Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska and Wyoming–already exempt sales tax for capital-intensive industries like data centers.
South Dakota shouldn’t miss out in reaping the benefits for its citizens and helping advance U.S. dominance in innovation.
text:
President Donald Trump has been clear in both his policies and rhetoric that he wants to help America win the next wave of technological innovation. But earlier this month, NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang sounded the alarm to the Financial Times: “China is going to win the AI race.” A critical step to help realize the President’s vision is to build more data centers, and South Dakota can help.

In America, we need more digital infrastructure. Essential components of that infrastructure are more data centers. These facilities house all the cloud storage for Americans and our businesses, and as we continue to use more tech tools, our need for more data centers grows. President Trump recognizes this need and is championing the rapid build-out of U.S. data centers for AI infrastructure, streamlining permitting and incentivizing investment so America creates good jobs and leads the global technology race. However, there have been three rising challenges to this build-out of critical digital infrastructure which must be addressed. Much of the information circulating on these topics as they relate to data centers is misleading at best: energy consumption, water use and taxes.

Data Centers Help Reduce Everyone Else’s Electricity Bills

By helping the state’s electrical utilities to modernize South Dakota’s grid, hyperscale data centers can build new power generation and transmission that improves reliability. At the same time, these large-load data centers will pay a greater share of the utilities’ fixed costs. This puts downward pressure on electricity bills for households.

New research for the U.S. Department of Energy by the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory found higher load growth from industries like data centers reduces electricity prices for other customers.

Berkeley’s research was featured in a Washington Post article, “There’s a reason electricity prices have been rising. And it’s not data centers.” Berkeley Labs found that North Dakota, which experienced a 40% increase in electricity demand thanks to new data centers, saw real electricity prices fall by 3 cents per kilowatt-hour. And Virginia, home to more data centers than anyone in the world, experienced a 14% increase in demand and a price drop of 1 cent per kilowatt-hour.

Berkeley Labs found that North Dakota, which experienced a 40% increase in electricity demand thanks to new data centers, saw real electricity prices fall by 3 cents per kilowatt-hour.

Moreover, in their 2024 study of Virginia’s data center industry, the Joint Legislative Audit Review Commission (JLARC) found that Virginia ratepayers are not footing the bill for data centers, and that the State Corporation Commission has the tools to continue to ensure ratepayer protection. According to Kansas electric utility Evergy, “Large load customers, including data centers, absorb a greater share of the fixed costs of operating grid infrastructure (power plants, poles and wires), thus lowering rates for all customers.”

Data centers invest in the local grid, bringing lower electricity bills and more reliable energy for South Dakota businesses and households.

Data Centers Use Less Water Than a Courthouse or Office Building

Many new large-scale data centers will consume less water than your average courthouse or office by using a high-tech version of the electricity-powered air conditioning similar to that which cools our homes, schools and businesses.

In the parts of South Dakota where water is abundant, new data centers could use evaporative cooling on the warmest days of the year to reduce electricity demand. In those data centers, some of the water would evaporate into the skies above South Dakota, just like an irrigated cornfield, reservoir or golf course. The water that doesn’t evaporate is then returned to the municipal system or aquifer, as approved by local and state water authorities. This efficient technology ensures that local water resources are used smartly and sparingly to protect the community’s water supply.

Virginia again leads by example on getting to the root of this issue. Being the state with the most data centers in the country, it performed a state audit that found that the data centers using water do so in a sustainable and well-regulated manner.

Data Center Property Taxes Provide Relief for Residential Taxpayers and New Community Investment

Sales tax is commonly exempted for manufacturing inputs and equipment. 35 states–including South Dakota’s neighbors North Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska and Wyoming–already exempt sales tax for capital-intensive industries like data centers. Hyperscale data centers are not built in states where they’re disproportionately taxed due to an outdated tax code, so without modernization, South Dakota will lose investment, jobs, and tax revenue to other states.

Moreover, data center builders bring substantial new property tax revenue to the communities where they locate, which provides property tax relief for homeowners, and funds local schools and infrastructure projects. This modernization brings an increase in property tax revenue for cities and counties. For example, Virginia’s data center industry contributes $9 billion to the state’s GDP and funds local schools and infrastructure. Virginia’s Loudoun County states that data center tax revenue “has enabled the county to reduce the real property tax rate for homeowners every year for the past decade.”

Virginia’s Loudoun County states that data center tax revenue “has enabled the county to reduce the real property tax rate for homeowners every year for the past decade.”

Modernizing South Dakota’s tax code to attract new industries like data centers will keep the Mount Rushmore State competitive with its neighbors and attract good jobs, investment and new property tax revenues.

As President Trump noted in July, “We believe that America’s destiny is to dominate every industry and be the first in every technology.” Data centers, essential digital infrastructure for the next generation of technological advancement, have already contributed 4.7 million American jobs and nearly $800 billion per year to our economy. South Dakota shouldn’t miss out in reaping the benefits for its citizens and helping advance U.S. dominance in innovation.

text:
Increasingly more expensive energy is resulting in higher late utility bills, a progressive think tank said in a report published Monday.

The Century Foundation, which focuses partially on economic equality, found that the average late balance on bills increased by nearly a third from early 2022 to this past summer. Monthly energy bills rose 35% over the same period, and families can’t keep up with payments, the organization noted.

“Our findings paint a grim picture: a toxic combination of increasing energy prices, rising overdue balances, and squeezed household budgets that together are pushing families deeper and deeper into debt,” The Century Foundation wrote.

“Furthermore, soaring utility bills are the tip of the iceberg for millions of Americans already overburdened by rising costs for health care, groceries, rent, child care, education, and more.”

Late balances for utility bills outpaced inflation 2.7 times during the studied period, according to the think tank. It said that Black families were three times more likely to have an overdue balance than white ones, noting that Black and Asian households also had the highest late bills.

“Energy insecurity follows the same racial fault lines as broader economic inequality, leaving communities of color more exposed to high balances and with less access to assistance,” The Century Foundation explained.

Late balances for families with well-below-average credit scores increased by 30% during the studied period, the organization added. Those households were disproportionately in urban and low-income neighborhoods, according to the think tank.

“These consumers are being especially pressed by the high cost of housing, food, child care, and transportation – and too often there’s not enough left over to pay the utility bill,” The Century Foundation said. “Not only does this leave them vulnerable to power cuts, but also it can be one more factor that further increases their cost of living and makes them vulnerable to having to take on new, costly debt just to make ends meet.”

The organization accused the Trump administration of failing to address the root causes of “energy inflation” and hindering the development of renewable energy.

President Donald Trump has targeted renewable energy projects by reducing federal support for them. He has said that sources like wind and solar are unreliable and worse options than oil and gas, which he claims are more beneficial for the economy.

The first day of his second term, Trump issued an executive order to protect the country’s “economic and national security” and “military preparedness” by making sure an “abundant” supply of reliable energy was available in every state.

“It is thus in the national interest to unleash America’s affordable and reliable energy and natural resources. This will restore American prosperity —- including for those men and women who have been forgotten by our economy in recent years,” the president said. “It will also rebuild our Nation’s economic and military security, which will deliver peace through strength.”

name: EPA
title: Trump Administration Plans to Gut Water Protections Nationwide - NRDC
description:
WASHINGTON, D.C. – The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced plans to strip Clean Water Act protections from millions of acres of wetlands and potentially millions of miles of streams across the country.
The proposed rule would dramatically narrow which waters are covered by federal safeguards, leaving many wetlands and headwaters vulnerable to pollution and destruction.
“By gutting protections for wetlands and streams, the EPA is trying to disown its legal obligation to protect our drinking water and our communities.
Wetlands are nature’s safeguard against flooding, and stripping away protections for them puts millions of people in harm’s way.
Background: The EPA’s new proposed rule sharply narrows which wetlands and streams are protected under the Clean Water Act.
text:
WASHINGTON, D.C. – The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced plans to strip Clean Water Act protections from millions of acres of wetlands and potentially millions of miles of streams across the country. The proposed rule would dramatically narrow which waters are covered by federal safeguards, leaving many wetlands and headwaters vulnerable to pollution and destruction. These waters are vital for filtering drinking water, reducing flood and drought risks, and sustaining wildlife—but under the planned rule, many of them would no longer be protected.

NRDC’s 2025 GIS analysis found that between 38 million and 70 million acres of wetlands are at risk of pollution or destruction under modeled scenarios similar to the changes the proposal includes.

“This is a reckless giveaway to polluters,” says Andrew Wetzler, senior vice president, Nature, at NRDC. “By gutting protections for wetlands and streams, the EPA is trying to disown its legal obligation to protect our drinking water and our communities. For the millions of Americans who swim or fish in our nation’s rivers and lakes, this is a bracing slap in the face. Wetlands are nature’s safeguard against flooding, and stripping away protections for them puts millions of people in harm’s way. At a time when climate change is fueling stronger storms and worsening floods, taking away these protections is not just shortsighted—it’s dangerous.”

“The EPA’s proposal is an extreme and unscientific exploitation of an already extreme and unscientific Supreme Court ruling,” says Jon Devine, director of freshwater ecosystems at NRDC. “Erasing protections for wetlands and streams that clearly affect downstream water quality and community safety ignores decades of hydrological science and will create regulatory chaos, leaving businesses, farmers, and communities with less certainty while exposing waters to more pollution.”

“Instead of undermining the Clean Water Act, the EPA should be building durable, science-based safeguards that honor both the law and the realities of how water moves across the landscape,” Devine says.

Background:

The EPA’s new proposed rule sharply narrows which wetlands and streams are protected under the Clean Water Act. The proposed rule would limit federal safeguards only to wetlands that hold surface water during the “wet season” and directly touch a water body like a river or stream that has continuous water flowing or standing during that “wet season.”

This approach excludes many critical wetlands and seasonal streams—waters that are essential for drinking water supplies, flood control, and ecosystem health.

Google’s $40 billion investment supports energy efficiency and workforce development and makes Texas Google’s largest investment in the nation.
text:
Google announces $40B investment in the Lone Star

State, Gov. Abbott highlights economic impact

ETR Staff Report

“They say that everything is bigger in Texas—and that certainly applies to the golden opportunity with AI.”

Sundar Pichai, Chief Executive Officer of Google

Texas recently received major economic news as Governor Greg Abbott and Google CEO Sundar Pichai jointly announced a $40 billion investment in Texas—Google’s largest investment in any state in the country. The funding is part of Google’s broader “Investing in America” initiative and will support cloud and artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure across the state.

Governor Abbott, speaking at the announcement event, emphasized the scale and significance of the investment.

“This is a Texas-sized investment in the future of our great state,” Abbott said. “Texas is the epicenter of AI development, where companies can pair innovation with expanding energy. Google’s $40 billion investment supports energy efficiency and workforce development and makes Texas Google’s largest investment in the nation. We must ensure that America remains at the forefront of the AI revolution, and Texas is the place where that can happen.”

Google’s investment includes the development of three new data center campuses, initiatives to strengthen energy capacity and affordability, and expanded workforce training programs for Texas students, electrical apprentices, and technology professionals.

“They say that everything is bigger in Texas—and that certainly applies to the golden opportunity with AI,” said Pichai. “This investment will create thousands of jobs, provide skills training to students and apprentices, and accelerate energy affordability initiatives throughout the state.”

Local communities across North Texas, West Texas, and the Panhandle are expected to see significant economic benefits, including job creation and opportunities for workers seeking careers in technology, engineering, and skilled trades. Google’s “Investing in America” initiative aims to strengthen U.S. competitiveness in the global AI landscape through major investments in infrastructure, research, energy capacity, and talent development.

U.S. Deputy Secretary of Energy James Danly, Google Global Head of Data Center Energy Amanda Peterson Corio, and various state officials attended the announcement.

As Texas continues to attract major technology investments, state leaders say the region is well positioned to remain a national leader in innovation and energy for years to come.

This rule would alleviate the confusion and delays caused by the prior administration’s policies, including its failure to fully implement the U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling in Sackett v. Environmental Protection Agency.

text:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17—Associated Builders and Contractors issued the following statement from its vice president of government affairs, Kristen Swearingen, on the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and U.S. Army Corps of Engineers release of a proposed rule that will clarify the definition of “waters of the United States”:

“ABC supports the Trump administration’s proposed rule to clarify the Clean Water Act’s definition of WOTUS. This rule would alleviate the confusion and delays caused by the prior administration’s policies, including its failure to fully implement the U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling in Sackett v. Environmental Protection Agency. We welcome the administration’s commitment to establishing a clear definition of WOTUS and reasonable boundaries on the scope of federal permitting.

“ABC looks forward to fully reviewing the Trump administration’s proposed rule and providing comments to assist the EPA and USACE in our shared goal of ensuring the efficient construction of critical infrastructure projects while maintaining water quality.”

name: EPA
title: Trump EPA Proposes Gutting Wetland and Stream Protections | Food & Water Watch
description:
Wetlands are critical to protecting clean water, providing habitat, and controlling flooding.
In response, Food & Water Watch Legal Director Tarah Heinzen issued the following statement: “Clean water is under attack in America, as polluting profiteers plunder our waters — Trump’s EPA is openly aiding and abetting this destruction.
This proposed rule weakens the bedrock Clean Water Act, making it easier to fill, drain, and pollute sensitive waterways from coast to coast.
Eliminating protections from small streams and wetlands will mean more pollution downstream — in our drinking water, at our beaches, and in our rivers.
Wetlands provide essential habitat and play an integral role in protecting clean water and reducing flooding.
text:
Proposed “Waters Of The U.S.” rule weakens bedrock Clean Water Act

Today, Trump’s Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) proposed a draft rule that eliminates bedrock Clean Water Act protections for rivers, streams, and wetlands by drastically narrowing what waterways will be considered “Waters of the United States.” The draft rule would compound the damage of the 2023 Sackett v. EPA Supreme Court decision, which eliminated protections for tens of millions of acres of sensitive wetlands and small streams. Wetlands are critical to protecting clean water, providing habitat, and controlling flooding.

In response, Food & Water Watch Legal Director Tarah Heinzen issued the following statement:

“Clean water is under attack in America, as polluting profiteers plunder our waters — Trump’s EPA is openly aiding and abetting this destruction. This proposed rule weakens the bedrock Clean Water Act, making it easier to fill, drain, and pollute sensitive waterways from coast to coast.

“This rule flies in the face of science and commonsense. Eliminating protections from small streams and wetlands will mean more pollution downstream — in our drinking water, at our beaches, and in our rivers. Wetlands provide essential habitat and play an integral role in protecting clean water and reducing flooding. These critical functions will only become more important as worsening climate change makes extreme weather more frequent. EPA must reverse course.”

name: Congress
title: NEPA, Judicial Review, and SPEED Act Roundtable Takeaways - Bipartisan Policy Center
description:
NEPA Reforms Policy Option 1: Clarify that NEPA is a procedural statute only and does not mandate specific environmental outcomes.
The National Environmental Policy Act, the first major environmental law in the United States, was signed by President Richard Nixon on January 1, 1970.
Policy Option 3: Allow the review process conducted under other federal statutes to satisfy NEPA review requirements.
Overall, most agreed that this policy option would reduce administrative burdens, while others felt this policy option was not particularly important.
Policy Option 13: Add “energy” to CEQ’s list of national policy goals, alongside conservation, social, economic, and health.
text:
Executive Summary

Policymakers across the political spectrum increasingly agree that modernizing the federal permitting process is essential to deploying energy infrastructure at the pace and scale needed to meet U.S. economic, environmental, and energy security goals. Despite this growing consensus, questions remain about the most effective options to make permitting more predictable, coordinated, and timely while maintaining key environmental safeguards and opportunities for public input.

As part of its ongoing effort to explore bipartisan approaches to permitting reform, the Bipartisan Policy Center convened a roundtable in October 2025 to discuss key provisions in the House of Representatives’ bipartisan Simplifying Permitting for Efficient and Effective Deployment (SPEED) Act. The roundtable focused on the version of the legislation introduced in July 2025 by Natural Resources Committee Chairman Bruce Westerman (R-AR) and Rep. Jared Golden (D-ME). The legislation proposes a range of reforms aimed at improving the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) permitting process, updating judicial review standards, and strengthening project certainty across federal agencies. The roundtable was composed of more than forty experts in energy and the intersection of energy and environmental issues, and conversation largely centered on those areas.

Participants broadly agreed that the current permitting system for critical energy infrastructure projects is too slow and unpredictable, and that reforms to NEPA and judicial review could meaningfully improve permitting timelines and project certainty. Participants largely supported the overall direction and intent of the SPEED Act, particularly the provisions designed to streamline environmental reviews by setting clearer limits on which environmental effects agencies must study, and to reduce litigation-driven delays. However, there was significant debate over the details, especially concerning the precision of statutory language, the balance between efficiency and environmental oversight, and the degree to which Congress should limit judicial remedies—such as injunctions or vacating permits.

While perspectives varied, the roundtable discussion reflected a shared commitment to improving the permitting process. Participants emphasized that careful drafting and bipartisan coordination are essential to ensure that any reforms—whether through the SPEED Act or a broader legislative package—strengthen efficiency and accountability, and are durable across several administrations and Congresses.

This roundtable builds on BPC’s continuing work to evaluate pragmatic permitting solutions. Previous discussions in this series have focused on various permitting subtopics, such as community engagement, linear infrastructure, and reforms to the Clean Water Act. Together, these convenings aim to identify realistic pathways toward a permitting reform framework that accelerates energy deployment while preserving public trust in environmental decision-making.

This roundtable discussion focused on 18 specific reforms proposed in the SPEED Act. The issue brief will summarize the discussion and areas of consensus and divergent opinions among the participants present.

NEPA Reforms

Policy Option 1: Clarify that NEPA is a procedural statute only and does not mandate specific environmental outcomes.

The National Environmental Policy Act, the first major environmental law in the United States, was signed by President Richard Nixon on January 1, 1970. The statute emerged amid growing public concern about air and water pollution, oil spills, and habitat destruction. These pressures pushed policymakers to recognize that federal decisions on infrastructure, development, and resource use could cause long-term damage to both natural and human environments, and that the government needed a more deliberate process for evaluating those impacts.

NEPA requires federal agencies to assess and disclose the environmental consequences of major actions before making decisions. The law established a framework for environmental reviews. Under this framework, agencies prepare environmental impact statements (EISs) for actions expected to have significant impacts and environmental assessments (EAs), which are categories of actions that the agency has determined do not normally have significant environmental impacts. Agencies may also rely on categorical exclusions (CEs), which are categories of actions that the agency has determined not to have significant environmental effects. Because CEs are defined in advance and grounded in experience, projects that fit within an existing CE can move through the NEPA process quicker, when compared to EISs and EAs.

Over time, NEPA’s scope and impact have evolved as courts, agencies, and regulators have expanded the scope of analysis required under the statute. Judicial interpretations have broadened what constitutes “significant” environmental effects, while agencies have conducted extensive and time-consuming reviews, mainly in an attempt to avoid or successfully defend against legal challenges. These trends have added layers of complexity to the process and resulted in longer review timelines and greater project uncertainty. As BPC’s SPEED Act explainer notes, the legislation clarifies that NEPA is a procedural statute that does not mandate any specific environmental outcomes.

Roundtable participants debated whether explicitly codifying that NEPA is a procedural statute would meaningfully improve permitting outcomes or simply reaffirm existing precedent (e.g., Seven County Infrastructure Coalition v. Eagle County (1970). Several participants noted that courts have long recognized NEPA as a procedural law and questioned whether legislative clarification would have any practical effect. Some suggested such clarification could help restore predictability and constrain the trend toward ever-expanding reviews. A few participants cautioned, however, that the courts and the public could interpret the effort to reaffirm NEPA’s original purpose as weakening environmental protection or limiting agencies’ flexibility to address new information or community concerns.

Overall, the roundtable agreed that NEPA should remain focused on transparency and informed decision-making rather than being the sole determiner of outcomes. Most participants supported reaffirming NEPA’s procedural foundation in principle, but opinions were split on whether doing so through legislation would offer tangible benefits.

Policy Option 2: Limit the scope of review to effects that are reasonably foreseeable and proximately caused by the project, excluding speculative or attenuated impacts, impacts separate in time or place, or those tied to separate projects.

Since NEPA’s enactment in 1970, both court decisions and agency practice, guided in part by CEQ’s 1978 regulations, have expanded what qualifies as an “effect”. Early cases like Calvert Cliffs’ Coordinating Committee v. Atomic Energy Commission (1971) required agencies to evaluate the environmental consequences of their actions. CEQ’s regulations, which for decades have shaped how executive agencies structure their NEPA processes, incorporated that approach by calling for the analysis of direct, indirect, and cumulative impacts. Although this more expansive practice strengthened environmental accountability, it has also broadened the scope of review beyond what some believe Congress originally intended and has contributed to lengthier permitting processes. The SPEED Act attempts to address this issue by clarifying that environmental review should focus on effects that are reasonably foreseeable and proximately caused by a project, excluding speculative or remote impacts.

Roundtable participants generally supported focusing environmental reviews on effects that are direct and foreseeable, but they raised concerns about how the proposed statutory language would function in practice. Many described the language as overly broad and imprecise, noting that it could create new uncertainty rather than streamline the review process. One participant observed that every effect could be thought of as separate in time and place. Some participants cautioned that the use of the word “limit” could be interpreted too narrowly and exclude legitimate analysis of indirect or cumulative effects that are often necessary to understand a project’s overall environmental impact.

Participants emphasized that this policy option’s effectiveness would depend on precise drafting in the legislation and clear guidance to agencies. Some warned that ambiguous or open-ended language could invite litigation over the scope of analysis and ultimately undermine the policy option’s goal of improving efficiency. Overall, thereF was broad agreement that clarifying NEPA’s scope could be helpful, but most participants viewed this policy option as too imprecise to achieve that goal without unintended consequences.

Policy Option 3: Allow the review process conducted under other federal statutes to satisfy NEPA review requirements.

NEPA reviews often overlap with other environmental statutes that impose similar requirements. For example, a single project may trigger review under the Clean Water Act for discharges, the Endangered Species Act for impacts on protected species, and the Clean Air Act for emissions. Each statute has its own standards, timelines, and administrative processes, often involving separate documentation, interagency consultations, and public comment periods. This overlap can result in duplicative analysis where multiple agencies examine the same environmental impacts under different statutes.

Participants generally viewed this policy option as a practical step toward reducing duplication in agency reviews. They noted, however, that the policy option lacks a clear process for determining when another statute’s review would be considered functionally equivalent to NEPA. One participant urged creating a transparent process for determining equivalence and pointed out that without it, this policy option could itself become a litigation magnet. Other participants noted that it was unclear which agencies would make the equivalence determination and how much detail would be required to demonstrate it. As an example to follow, participants pointed to the permitting process for Class VI wells in which the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) gives primacy to states.

Overall, participants supported the policy option’s intent and agreed that clarifying when and how existing federal reviews can satisfy NEPA requirements could help reduce redundant analysis, if the legislation clearly defines the process for establishing equivalence.

Policy Option 4: Allow state or tribal reviews to satisfy NEPA requirements if these reviews determine that applicants have met NEPA standards.

This option builds on policy option three’s discussion of functional equivalence among federal statutes by extending the same concept to state and tribal environmental reviews. In some cases, states already conduct assessments that are similar in scope to NEPA, such as California’s Environmental Quality Act. This option aims to clarify that federal agencies could rely on these state or tribal reviews—when they meet NEPA standards—thereby avoiding repetitive review of the same project impacts.

Some participants suggested that if a state process is functionally equivalent to NEPA, a federal agency should be able to rely on that analysis to avoid duplication. Others cautioned that this could disincentivize states from reforming their own review processes and argued that the federal government should focus on improving NEPA rather than relying on varying state standards. Discussion on this policy option was brief, with one participant expressing support while another questioned whether it could backfire, depending on which agency determines equivalence. Overall, most participants emphasized that the onus should be on the federal government to improve NEPA.

Policy Option 5: Prohibit agencies from rescinding or altering completed environmental documents unless ordered to do so by a court.

Under current practice, federal agencies can revisit or withdraw previously finalized environmental documents or project approvals, sometimes following changes in presidential administration or policy direction. These reversals require project sponsors to repeat parts of the review process or halt construction despite having completed the required environmental reviews. These follow-up actions can increase uncertainty and project risk, increase costs, undermine long-term planning, and discourage investment.

Participants broadly supported efforts to strengthen project certainty and prevent completed environmental reviews from being reopened or withdrawn without cause. Several described this policy option as an important way to ensure stability across administrations and to give developers confidence that projects can move forward once reviews are complete. However, several participants emphasized that precise statutory language would be essential to make this provision effective and to avoid unintended consequences. A few participants questioned whether such language would actually prevent bad-faith rescissions, as agencies could still find other avenues to reopen reviews, and they suggested including an option requiring project sponsors to concur when an agency identifies a genuine error.

Policy Option 6: Require statements of purpose and need in environmental documents to align with the goals of the project applicant.

Under NEPA, an agency’s statement of purpose and need defines the objectives of a proposed project and guides the range of alternatives analyzed in an EA or EIS. In practice, agencies must evaluate a range of alternatives that could meet those objectives, including the project proposed by the applicant, a “no action” option, and other feasible approaches. When the agency defines the purpose differently than the applicant, it can expand the scope of alternatives, lengthen review timelines, and create tension over whether the agency has effectively redefined the project itself.

The SPEED Act includes this policy option to clarify that purpose and need statements should align with the applicant’s goals. This would ensure that agencies evaluate alternatives relevant to the project being proposed rather than redefining its objectives.

Participants discussed whether this policy option would appropriately balance agency authority with applicant goals. One participant cited Burlington v. Busey (1990), noting that courts have found agency authority to be primary in defining a project’s purpose. They cautioned that writing applicant goals directly into statute could invite courts or agencies to interpret the provision as a mandate to defer to the applicant’s definition in all circumstances, potentially constraining legitimate agency discretion. Several participants cautioned that a strained civil service capacity could also complicate implementation. Others agreed that while agency authority should remain primary, agencies should also consider the applicant’s goals when determining whether a project falls within their statutory authority. Overall, participants agreed that the underlying problem is real, but several were unsure whether this policy option was the right statutory fix.

Policy Option 7: Allow deadline extensions only with a project applicant’s approval.

NEPA includes statutory time limits for environmental reviews—generally, one year for EAs and two years for EISs—as established by the 2023 Fiscal Responsibility Act. Under current law, those deadlines may be extended only with the approval of the project applicant, after consultation with cooperating agencies. The SPEED Act builds on those provisions by specifying that any extensions to those timelines can be granted only with the approval of the project applicant. Supporters view this as a way to give developers greater certainty over project timelines and to discourage unnecessary delays, while maintaining flexibility for cases where additional time is genuinely needed.

Participants discussed how this policy option would interact with existing statutory timelines and agency practice. Several participants raised broader questions about whether deadlines are effective at all and whether this policy option is needed. Some cautioned that stricter limits could push more NEPA work into the preapplication period, effectively hiding how long reviews take. Others suggested that pairing firm timelines with stronger judicial review provisions could make the process more effective. Overall, participants agreed that the policy option’s intent to enhance accountability and predictability was sound, but views differed on whether requiring applicant approval would meaningfully improve review timelines.

Policy Option 8: Agencies do not have to undertake or consider new studies after an application is submitted or a notice of intent is issued.

This provision in the SPEED Act is intended to prevent permitting delays that occur when agencies initiate or evaluate new studies after a project application has been submitted or a notice of intent has been issued. In current practice, new information, such as recently published studies or data, can prompt additional analysis or supplemental environmental documents and extend review timelines. This policy option intends to provide greater certainty by clarifying that agencies are not obligated to undertake or consider new studies introduced after the review process has formally begun.

Participants expressed a mix of support and concern regarding this policy option. Several agreed that the intent was sensible and could help reduce delays. Others worried that the language might be interpreted too broadly and would prevent agencies from considering new information that could materially affect environmental outcomes. Furthermore, some participants noted that this policy option could create confusion about how agencies should handle studies completed after a draft EIS is issued. Overall, participants agreed that while the goal of improving timeliness was sound, careful drafting would be needed to ensure that agencies retain the ability to consider relevant new information when appropriate. Last, some participants recommended tying the cutoff to the issuance of a draft EIS, which they viewed as a more defensible point to limit new information.

Policy Option 9: Require agencies not to delay review to await anticipated new studies.

Environmental reviews under NEPA can take years to complete, and one contributing factor is agencies delaying action while awaiting anticipated new studies, datasets, or modeling results. Such delays can extend project timelines even when the existing information is sufficient to complete the review. The SPEED Act includes this policy option to clarify that agencies should proceed with their analysis using currently available information rather than pausing to await future studies.

Participants discussed this policy option briefly. Some viewed it as a logical companion to the previous provision on new studies, intended to prevent agencies from using anticipated research as a reason to postpone project reviews. However, others questioned whether the intent was to avoid unnecessary delays or to permit agencies to disregard potentially relevant information. The roundtable ultimately did not reach consensus on this policy option.

Policy Option 10: Extend the window of programmatic EIS/EA documents from five years to 10 years, subject to reevaluation.

A programmatic environmental impact statement or environmental assessment analyzes the environmental effects of a broader policy, program, plan, or group of related actions rather than a single project. These documents allow agencies to “tier” subsequent, project-specific reviews from the broader analysis. Agencies generally reevaluate programmatic analyses every five years to determine whether new circumstances or information require supplementation.

The SPEED Act would double this window and extend the period in which agencies may rely on a programmatic document from five years to 10 years. The goal is to reduce the frequency of reevaluations, improve predictability, and allow agencies to extend the use of resource-intensive programmatic analyses.

Participants had mixed opinions on this policy option. Some supported it, describing it as a straightforward improvement that would make programmatic reviews more useful. A few participants questioned whether extending the timeframe would make a significant difference in practice and pointed out the difficulty in predicting future conditions.

Several participants suggested that programmatic reviews could be especially valuable for energy transition minerals (such as lithium, nickel, cobalt, and rare earth elements used in the production of clean energy technologies), where environmental conditions and resource locations are unlikely to change significantly over a decade. One participant noted that landscapes involving nickel or other mineral deposits evolve slowly, making a 10-year window appropriate. Overall, most agreed that this policy option would reduce administrative burdens, while others felt this policy option was not particularly important.

Policy Option 11: Allow agencies to adopt categorical exclusions established by agencies, including those legislated by Congress.

Under current practice, agencies may adopt CEs in another agency’s NEPA procedures if they determine that it fits their own activities and complies with applicable requirements. Although CEQs guidance has historically shaped how agencies develop and use CEs, the Supreme Court’s recent Seven Counties decision has clarified that CEQ’s regulations do not carry binding force for all federal agencies. As a result, agency-specific NEPA procedures, rather than CEQ regulations, now govern the establishment and application of CEs.

The SPEED Act would expand existing authority by allowing agencies to apply CEs that were created by Congress for another agency. For example, a statutory CE created by Congress for the Department of Transportation could be applied by the Department of Energy (DOE) for a similar class of infrastructure projects. This change aims to reduce duplication and streamline reviews by allowing agencies to rely on statutory CEs rather than conducting new analyses for similar actions.

Participants generally viewed this policy option favorably. Several said it would reduce redundant analysis and improve efficiency by allowing agencies to make use of CEs that Congress has already designated. There was no significant opposition, and participants characterized the policy option as a practical step to streamlining permitting.

Policy Option 12: Narrow the definition of “major federal action.”

Under NEPA, environmental review is required for “major federal actions significantly affecting the quality of the environment.” This phrase determines when NEPA applies, and its interpretation has long been debated. There is no definition of “major federal action” within NEPA, although the recent Fiscal Responsibility Act added a list of actions that are explicitly not considered major federal actions. The SPEED Act would modify and expand that list.

Under current law, certain forms of federal assistance are excluded from NEPA when the federal agency lacks sufficient control over the project. The SPEED Act would tighten this standard by specifying that such assistance is not a major federal action unless the agency has “complete control and responsibility” over the project; it would also add grants, farm loans, and guarantees to the list of excluded actions and clarify that federal funding alone does not trigger NEPA.

Participants widely agreed that the goal of this policy option is important but raised concerns about the proposed language. Several commented that “complete control” seemed too narrow and could create loopholes that allow agencies to avoid environmental review. A participant noted that narrowing the definition of a major federal action could have potential consequences, such as allowing the federal government to avoid NEPA for projects in which it has substantial involvement (e.g., “Alligator Alcatraz”) or for other projects where agencies provide significant funding or approvals but could still claim they lack “complete control and responsibility.” This could create pathways to bypass NEPA despite meaningful federal influence over a project’s outcome.

Participants pointed out that DOE and other agencies often enter into cooperative agreements, where the federal government exercises significant but not complete control. Some supported this change, questioning whether projects receiving federal cost shares should be treated differently from identical projects developed without federal funding.

Additionally, some participants argued that NEPA should apply when federal funding influences project design or siting decisions, but not when funds are distributed after a project is already planned or underway. One participant cited as a potential model certain thresholds at the U.S. Department of Agriculture, where projects below 5% federal funding typically do not trigger NEPA, those between 5% and one-third are decided on a case-by-case basis, and those above one-third normally require review.

A few participants emphasized the need to explicitly define “major federal action” in statute to avoid decades of inconsistent case law and administrative interpretation. Others urged “not to let the perfect be the enemy of the good,” noting that this provision in the SPEED Act could incentivize greater cooperation between developers and agencies even if it does not fully resolve the issue.

Policy Option 13: Add “energy” to CEQ’s list of national policy goals, alongside conservation, social, economic, and health.

The Council on Environmental Quality issues governmentwide NEPA guidance and maintains a statement of environmental policy goals that federal agencies often use to inform their decision-making. These goals emphasize the conservation of natural resources, the balance of economic and environmental priorities, and the promotion of social and health welfare. The SPEED Act would add “energy” to the list of national policy goals. The intent is to recognize energy development as a core national objective and ensure it is considered in federal decision-making processes.

Most participants viewed this policy option favorably, describing it as a symbolic but useful acknowledgment of energy’s important role in national policy. Several noted that energy could already fall under the existing “economic” goal but agreed that explicitly naming it could help guide how agencies balance priorities.

Judicial Review Reforms

Policy Option 14: Establish a two-part test for overturning agency actions.

Under the Administrative Procedure Act, courts overturn agency decisions if they find them “arbitrary and capricious.” In practice, this has allowed courts to vacate permits even for procedural NEPA errors that may have no bearing on an agency’s final decision. To address this issue, the SPEED Act would establish a stricter, two-part test for judicial review: A court could overturn or reject an agency decision based on its noncompliance with NEPA only if it finds both that the agency “abused its substantial discretion” when rendering its decision, and that its decision would have been different but for that abuse of discretion. In short, the goal is to limit judicial intervention to truly consequential NEPA analytical and decisional errors and provide greater project certainty once reviews are complete.

Participants viewed this option as a major change that would raise the bar for overturning agency decisions. Several described the second part—requiring proof that the outcome would have changed but for the agency’s NEPA error—as the most important feature, as it would prevent costly injunctions and remands (when a court sends a decision back to an agency) when a procedural flaw has no decisive effect. Others questioned what “abuse of substantial discretion” means as a legal standard and whether it merely restates the existing “arbitrary and capricious” test.

Some participants supported this policy option in principle but worried that the threshold could be too high and could make it difficult to correct genuine deficiencies in environmental reviews. Overall, the group agreed that the policy option aims to reduce unnecessary litigation and improve predictability, but many emphasized that its effectiveness would depend on how courts interpret and apply the new standard.

Policy Option 15: Prohibit courts from substituting their judgment on environmental effects for that of the agency.

Under NEPA, courts sometimes evaluate not just whether an agency followed proper procedures but whether its conclusions about environmental impacts were reasonable. This review can allow judges to second-guess technical decisions and effectively redo an agency’s analysis. The second-guessing can contribute to uncertainty and inconsistency across jurisdictions. To address this issue, the SPEED Act clarifies that courts may not substitute their own judgment for that of the agency when they review environmental effects.

Participants expressed mixed views on this policy option. Several questioned how courts could determine whether an agency would have reached a different decision (the standard set forth in Policy Option 14 above) without substituting their own judgment—a contradiction between the policy options that one participant described as “impossible to reconcile.” Others felt the language simply restated existing practice, noting that the Supreme Court’s recent Seven Counties decision reaffirmed that NEPA is a procedural statute and that courts may not second-guess an agency’s expert technical judgments so long as the agency has taken a ‘hard look’. A few participants appreciated the intent to limit unnecessary judicial intervention but doubted this language would be effective in doing so, as judges would likely interpret it inconsistently.

Policy Option 16: Limit court remedies to remand with instructions and deadlines (judges could not issue injunctions or vacate permits).

Currently, when courts find a violation under NEPA, they can vacate the permit or issue injunctions while agencies correct deficiencies in their analyses. These remedies can add to project costs even if the judicially determined defect is procedural or would not change the agency’s permitting decision. The SPEED Act would limit courts to remanding a case to the agency with instructions specifying what needs to be fixed in the analysis and a deadline of no more than 180 days. This approach is intended to provide greater project certainty by preventing minor issues from delaying project commencement.

Although many in the room favored the increased use of remand with instructions over injunctions or vacating permits, most participants opposed this policy option as written. Several said that if courts cannot vacate permits or issue injunctions, NEPA would be left without any real enforcement power. Some argued that this remedy might not be sufficient when the bar for court action had been raised to “substantial abuse” by the relevant agency. Others agreed that while lengthy litigation can delay projects, they felt that this approach went beyond what could be supported in a bipartisan deal. Some participants argued that the policy option might help agencies and developers keep projects moving while minor issues are resolved. Overall, participants viewed this as one of the most controversial provisions in the SPEED Act.

Policy Option 17: Shorten the statute of limitations for NEPA challenges to 150 days.

Currently lawsuits challenging NEPA reviews can, in most cases, be filed up to six years after a permit approval. This leaves agencies and developers uncertain long after the review has been completed and a permit issued. The SPEED Act would shorten the statute of limitations for filing NEPA challenges to 150 days after the final agency action.

Every participant agreed with the intent of this policy option and described a three- to six-month window as reasonable. Overall, the consensus was that shortening the statute of limitations would help ensure earlier resolution of disputes and reduce project uncertainty.

Policy Option 18: Restrict standing to parties who submitted substantive, detailed comments during the public comment period.

Under current law, individuals and organizations can file NEPA lawsuits even if they did not participate during the public comment process. The SPEED Act would limit standing to parties that submitted unique, substantive, and detailed comments during the public comment period, raised the same issues in litigation, and can demonstrate direct harm.

Participants generally agreed that linking standing to participation during the public comment process could reduce unnecessary litigation and promote earlier engagement. Many pointed to the Fast-41 permitting framework as precedent for this type of reform but affirmed that the SPEED Act’s version appears more restrictive. Several participants warned that requiring both detailed comments and proof of harm could disadvantage smaller organizations, tribes, or under-resourced communities that lack the capacity to produce highly technical submissions. Others supported the idea in principle but said the timing of public comment opportunities, particularly if limited to the notice of intent stage, could further constrain meaningful participation. Overall, many participants supported the intention of this policy option but agreed that the current language may need to be adjusted to ensure communities can still access judicial review.

Conclusion

To improve the permitting process, roundtable participants agreed on the need to reform NEPA and judicial review. And participants mostly agreed that the SPEED Act’s policy options seek to solve real problems in the current system. Some of these options enjoyed consensus support, but others did not. Most importantly, participants agreed that improvements to NEPA and judicial review are necessary components of a broader permitting reform package that is also likely to include other key policies, such as project certainty and improvements to permitting for transmission and other linear infrastructure.

This roundtable builds on BPC’s ongoing work to develop pragmatic, bipartisan permitting solutions. Following this discussion on the SPEED Act’s NEPA and judicial review provisions, BPC will next convene a roundtable focused on project certainty and predictability, with a focus on the objective of ensuring that all project types are treated fairly and consistently across presidential administrations.

name: Congress
title: E.P.A. Drastically Limits Protections for Wetlands - The New York Times
description:
The proposed rule could strip federal protections from millions of acres of wetlands and streams, potentially threatening sources of clean drinking water for millions of Americans.
Under the Clean Water Act, companies and individuals must obtain a permit from the E.P.A.
A 2023 Supreme Court decision had set the stage for the E.P.A.’s action by curtailing the agency’s power to police millions of acres of wetlands.
E.P.A., Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. wrote that the Clean Water Act allowed the agency to regulate only wetlands with a “continuous surface connection” to a “relatively permanent” body of water.
These changes could strip federal protections from up to 55 million acres of wetlands, or about 85 percent of all wetlands nationwide, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group.
text:
The Trump administration proposed on Monday to significantly limit the Environmental Protection Agency’s authority to limit pollution in wetlands, rivers and other bodies of water across the country.

The proposed rule could strip federal protections from millions of acres of wetlands and streams, potentially threatening sources of clean drinking water for millions of Americans. It was a victory for a range of business interests that have lobbied to scale back the Clean Water Act of 1972, including farmers, home builders, real estate developers, oil drillers and petrochemical manufacturers.

“I know that across the country, news of today’s proposal is going to be met with a lot of relief from farmers, ranchers, other landowners and governments,” said Lee Zeldin, the E.P.A. administrator, during an event at the agency’s headquarters in Washington featuring Republican members of Congress and industry executives.

Under the Clean Water Act, companies and individuals must obtain a permit from the E.P.A. before releasing pollutants into the nation’s waterways. They must receive a permit from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers before discharging any dredged or fill material, such as sand, silt or construction debris.

A 2023 Supreme Court decision had set the stage for the E.P.A.’s action by curtailing the agency’s power to police millions of acres of wetlands. In the majority opinion in Sackett v. E.P.A., Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. wrote that the Clean Water Act allowed the agency to regulate only wetlands with a “continuous surface connection” to a “relatively permanent” body of water.

But Justice Alito did not explicitly define a “relatively permanent” body of water. Now, the Trump administration is describing it as a body of water that flows either year-round or during the “wet season.”

The new definition would exclude wetlands that abut or touch many intermittent streams, which do not flow during dry periods. It also could exclude ephemeral streams, which sit dry for much of the year and fill up only after rainfall or snowmelt.

These changes could strip federal protections from up to 55 million acres of wetlands, or about 85 percent of all wetlands nationwide, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group.

“The administration is preparing to rip away protections from the vast majority of wetlands in the United States, which are the waters that protect our communities from floods, help filter drinking water and provide habitat for millions of birds and fish,” said Andrew Wetzler, senior vice president for nature at N.R.D.C.

Ephemeral streams can be small, but a recent study found that they provided about 55 percent of the water flowing through most river systems used in drinking water supplies.

“This rule will mean more unsafe drinking water and more expensive water treatment costs for taxpayers,” said Jim Murphy, senior director of legal advocacy at the National Wildlife Federation, a conservation group.

The National Association of Home Builders, an industry trade group, praised the Trump administration’s proposal, saying it would slash costs for builders and developers, potentially lowering the price of new homes. “This is a significant step toward reducing regulatory red tape, cutting permitting costs and lowering the cost of doing business in communities across the country — all while continuing to protect our nation’s vital waterways,” Buddy Hughes, chairman of the association, said in a statement.

Representative Bruce Westerman, Republican of Arkansas and chairman of the House Committee on Natural Resources, said the proposal would help fix a “broken” permitting process in the United States. “We’re losing our ability to build things here in America,” he said at the E.P.A. event.

Ever since Congress passed the Clean Water Act to protect all “waters of the United States,” policymakers in Washington have been squabbling over how, exactly, to define those bodies of water.

In 2015, the Obama administration widened the law’s scope to cover smaller streams and headwaters. Several Republican-led states challenged the rule in court as an example of regulatory overreach, leading a federal judge to pause its implementation.

During Mr. Trump’s first term, the E.P.A. repealed the Obama-era rule and issued a weaker version. Then in 2023 the Supreme Court ruled in Sackett v. E.P.A., dealing a setback to the Biden administration’s efforts to again strengthen the regulation.

The Sackett case concerned an Idaho couple, Michael and Chantell Sackett, who sought to build a house on what an appeals court called “a soggy residential lot” near a lake. The E.P.A. determined that there were wetlands on the property, and it ordered the couple to stop construction or risk paying fines of more than $40,000 per day.

The Sacketts, represented by the conservative Pacific Legal Foundation, sued. The case reached the Supreme Court, which ruled that the couple’s 0.63-acre lot — and other properties like it nationwide — was not subject to federal oversight.

“This proposed rule is significant not just for small landowners like the Sacketts, but for all sectors of the regulated community, whether it’s agriculture or home construction or industrial development,” said Damien Schiff, a senior attorney with the Pacific Legal Foundation.

After the proposal is published in the Federal Register, the E.P.A. will solicit public comments for 45 days before finalizing the rule.

name: EPA
title: EPA's Narrowed Definition of WOTUS Threatens Water Quality - Waterkeeper
description:
By narrowing the scope of waters protected under the Clean Water Act, this reinterpretation removes federal safeguards from many rivers, streams, lakes, wetlands, and other vital waterways.
Without oversight, these waters face increased risks from pollution, threatening clean drinking water, recreation, fisheries, and aquatic life.
“Every rollback threatens the water we drink, the rivers we fish, and the wetlands that protect our communities and ecosystems,” said Kelly Hunter Foster, Senior Attorney for Waterkeeper Alliance.
“EPA’s new draft WOTUS rule continues to prioritize corporate interests by compromising the already weakened protections for thousands of water bodies across the country.
Waterkeeper Alliance will keep fighting for the clean water that we all need and deserve.”
text:
November 17, 2025

Waterkeeper Alliance is sounding the alarm about the newly announced draft rule from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Department of the Army to revise the definition of the “waters of the United States” (WOTUS), which further undermines landmark clean water protections, threatening water quality across the United States.

By narrowing the scope of waters protected under the Clean Water Act, this reinterpretation removes federal safeguards from many rivers, streams, lakes, wetlands, and other vital waterways. Without oversight, these waters face increased risks from pollution, threatening clean drinking water, recreation, fisheries, and aquatic life.

The Clean Water Act has already been severely weakened following the Supreme Court’s 2023 decision in Sackett v. EPA, in which the Court dramatically revoked protections for thousands of bodies of water across the country. This new draft rule takes these rollbacks even further and follows EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin’s plans earlier this year to revise wastewater regulations for coal-burning power plants, roll back coal ash management regulations, and reconsider the Mercury and Air Toxics Standards. He has also withdrawn standards that could have cleaned up water pollution from slaughterhouses, announced plans to weaken PFAS drinking water standards, and ordered the closure of EPA offices responsible for addressing disproportionate pollution in low-income and rural communities and communities of color.

Collectively, these actions threaten to reverse more than five decades of progress to reduce highly toxic and dangerous pollutants from the environment and protect critical water resources from dangerous development projects.

“Every rollback threatens the water we drink, the rivers we fish, and the wetlands that protect our communities and ecosystems,” said Kelly Hunter Foster, Senior Attorney for Waterkeeper Alliance. “EPA’s new draft WOTUS rule continues to prioritize corporate interests by compromising the already weakened protections for thousands of water bodies across the country. This isn’t abstract policy, it’s a deliberate decision that disregards the real consequences for people’s health, safety, and daily lives. Waterkeeper Alliance will keep fighting for the clean water that we all need and deserve.”

description:
