text:
November 17, 2025

Contact Information

EPA Press Office (press@epa.gov)

WASHINGTON – Today, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Lee Zeldin shared 100 additional environmental accomplishments EPA has achieved in the last 100 days, recognizing 300 days of fulfilling the agency’s statutory obligations, and delivering clean air, land, and water for all Americans under President Donald Trump's leadership.

This progress includes announcing a proposed rule today that establishes a clear, durable, common-sense definition of “waters of the United States” (WOTUS), completing 100 days of "pressure testing" Tijuana-San Diego wastewater projects from the July 2025 U.S.-Mexico Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) and accelerating timelines by nine months, secured our border from dangerous illegal pesticides through enforcement action, led emergency response efforts and cleanup efforts in communities across the nation, and so much more.

These 100 actions build on Administrator Zeldin’s list of 100 pro-environmental actions taken by the agency during President Trump’s First 100 Days in office and another 100 pro-environmental actions highlighted at the 200-day milestone to total 300 featured accomplishments.

"We are thrilled to announce another 100 top accomplishments from the last 100 days in our mission to meet our statutory duties and defend human health and environmental quality," said EPA Administrator Zeldin. "The Trump EPA is showing that we can be exceptional environmental stewards while Powering the Great American Comeback. 300 days, 300 major environmental wins – this is the energy that propels us forward and the pace that motivates us. We will keep working tirelessly to secure success after success for America's environment and families nationwide."

This snapshot represents the great work done by the agency on a daily basis as EPA continues to fulfill its core mission of protecting human health and the environment, while committing to commonsense policies that drive down prices, unleash American energy, advance permitting reform and cooperative federalism, make America the AI capital of the world, and revitalize the auto industry.

Announced a proposed rule that establishes a clear, durable, common-sense definition of WOTUS under the Clean Water Act.

Completed 100 days of "pressure testing" Tijuana-San Diego wastewater projects following the July 2025 U.S.-Mexico MOU, accelerating timelines by nine months while advancing funding discussions with Mexico that will contribute to permanently ending the flow of raw sewage from Mexico into the United States.

Issued an Interim Final Rule to cut red tape on the temporary-use Commercial and Industrial Solid Waste Incinerators (CISWI) for natural disaster debris removal, providing state, local and Tribal governments with the ability to quickly and effectively clean up their communities

Issued guidance directing regional offices to work with local, state, Tribal, and federal partners to remove barriers in State Implementation Plans (SIPs) that discourage prescribed fires.

Established orders under Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) Section 5(e) for 68 new chemicals that may present unreasonable risk.

Proposed 144 and finalized 170 significant new use rules (SNURs) under TSCA for chemicals approved in the new chemicals program, ensuring these chemicals do not pose unreasonable risks to human health or the environment.

Decreased the backlog of pesticide submissions under review by over 5,200 from the start of the Administration to the beginning of November, ensuring growers and other users have the tools they need to protect our food supply, combat pests and respond to other public health and environmental issues.

Hosted a webinar for almost 400 building code officials covering lead hazards, EPA lead-safe work certification requirements, and protective practices during home renovations.

Streamlined review processes for over 3,000 company chemical risk notifications (including PFAS and pesticides), distributing 900+ to improve regulatory decisions protecting human health and the environment.

Issued vital guidance needed for publishing bilingual labels to better protect farmworkers and other users from pesticide exposures and ensure proper use.

Held a webinar attended by 882 participants aimed at training farmers, applicators, and other users on how to comply with Endangered Species Act label mitigations.

Secured U.S. border from dangerous pesticides and chemicals through enforcement actions resulting in 13 total defendants, $6.3 million in financial penalties, and 29 months imprisonment.

Concluded 1,778 enforcement cases, which will reduce, treat, or eliminate nearly 86 million pounds of air, chemical, and water pollution.

Concluded 41 enforcement cases totaling more than $714.4 million for past and future Superfund cleanup work addressing more than 58.8 million cubic yards of contaminated soil and water.

Conducted 6,457 inspections and 3,807 offsite compliance monitoring activities.

Issued the Residential Lead Directive for CERCLA Sites and RCRA Hazardous Waste Cleanup Program Facilities.

Announced the selection of 25 communities to receive assistance through the Recreation Economy for Rural Communities.

Distributed $86.2 million in supplemental Hurricane Helene recovery funds to support debris removal, management, and property reuse evaluation.

Hosted the biennial Brownfields conference with over 2,600 stakeholders, offering 185 sessions and eight workshops focused on sharing best practices for contaminated property remediation and redevelopment.

Signed 10 Clean Air Act regulatory actions in New England including 5 final State Implementation Plan (SIP) rulemakings.

Issued nine TSCA PCB Cleanup and Disposal Approvals to support New England infrastructure and redevelopment.

Finalized a consent order requiring removal of PFAS foam and system cleaning at Brunswick Executive Airport in Maine.

Signed Interim Record of Decision for the Tinkham Garage Superfund Site in New Hampshire to address contamination in drinking water.

Signed an Action Memo to mobilize cleanup efforts of PCBs and lead in a Dartmouth, Massachusetts, residential neighborhood.

Completed decision document for cleanup at Lower Neponset River Superfund Site in Massachussetts to remove contaminated soil and sediment, stabilize and restore riverbanks.

Conducted outreach on the Renovation, Repair, and Painting Rule (RRP) to 689 companies and individuals in Maine with lapsed certifications, sponsored training, and approved training provider accreditation.

Approved revised Clean Water Act Section 320 Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan to protect and restore Great Bay and Hampton-Seabrook estuary watersheds in New Hampshire.

Installed 108 Point of Entry Treatment water systems to address PFAS contamination and sampled over 350 wells and provided bottled water to almost 200 residents near the Route 31 Sludge Superfund removal site in New Jersey.

Finalized agreement with NRGY Development, LLC, requiring asbestos contamination removal to secure the former Goudey Power Station Site in New York.

Issued a Clean Water Act National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit for EcoEléctrica, a company that produces about 15% of Puerto Rico’s electricity.

Reached settlement with the Newark Housing Authority requiring lead testing and abatement across 11 pre-1978 properties housing about 5,500 residents in New Jersey.

Issued a Safe Drinking Water Act order to the City of Syracuse, New York, requiring improvements and public education to address lead in the water.

Issued a Unilateral Administrative Order under Superfund law requiring Messer LLC to perform vapor intrusion mitigation for the Cinnaminson Groundwater Contamination Superfund Site in New Jersey.

Responded to a serious fire in Gorham, New York, establishing air monitoring and developing plans to address flareups while working to remove hazardous substances (primarily expired hand sanitizer).

Completed removal of approximately 100,000 gallons of expired hand sanitizer and 30 cubic yards of contaminated soil from Niagara Falls, New York.

Gained full accreditation to perform a sophisticated analysis for toxic volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the air in Region 2.

Expedited evaluation of Maryland's Animal Feeding Operations Discharge Permit in just 27 days, reducing permit review time by 70%.

Conducted extensive sampling at Atlantic Wood Industries Superfund Site in Virginia, analyzing over 1,500 oysters to evaluate remedial success.

Hosted over 60 federal and state stakeholders for collaborative training on environmental remediation, groundwater investigation, and radon risk reduction in Region 3.

Strengthened multi-agency preparedness with training on train derailments, radiological security, oil spills, and hazardous materials emergency planning and response.

Advanced clean water protections through approved selenium criteria in Virginia and new sediment total maximum daily limits.

Completed oyster reef recovery in 10 target tributaries and restored more than 2,900 acres of habitat with Chesapeake Bay partners.

Forged first-ever Agriculture Memorandum of Understanding with Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services to expand collaboration on agricultural practices that benefit the environment, regulatory and compliance programs, training, communication, and education.

Launched a new macroinvertebrate subsampling station at Fort Mifflin in Pennsylvania to strengthen regional Clean Water Act monitoring.

Removed 1,815 pounds of contamination at Southern Solvents Superfund Site in Tampa, Florida, and achieved the Remedial Action goal.

Sampled 515 residential properties, remediated 161 properties, and disposed of more than 30,000 tons of contaminated material to safeguard residents from lead exposure at the Southside Chattanooga Lead Superfund Site in Tennessee.

Completed a $1.98 million cleanup at Continental Cleaners Superfund Site in Miami, Florida, that protects the Biscayne aquifer, Miami-Dade's sole source of drinking water.

Provided Risk Assessment training to 40 state project managers in Columbia, South Carolina.

Finalized a report on particulate Action Levels related to metal emissions from lithium-ion battery fires to enhance and guide protective actions.

Enhanced EPA's partnership with Citrus County, Florida, to advance $1.2 million for the Septic-to-Sewer program.

Distributed $685 million for recovery in partnership with FEMA and local officials, resulting in 122 pre-application projects in 59 communities for flood risk reduction and resiliency enhancement, as we recently marked the first anniversary since the devastation of Hurricane Helene.

Worked to collect 54,000 gallons of oil-water mix, stabilize nearby waterways and drinking water sources, and prevent further contamination following the UPS Flight 2976 crash in Louisville, Kentucky.

Collaborated with Department of Energy (DOE) on the first land lease in the nation under the Hall Amendment for beneficial site redevelopment with lease of 100-acre parcel of Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant Superfund site.

Completed two-year residential cleanup project addressing PCB-contaminated soil at 56 properties on the Ten Mile Drain Superfund site in Kentucky.

Approved Michigan's regional haze state implementation plan revisions, addressing pollution that causes visibility issues at national parks and wilderness areas.

Completed a time-critical cleanup of a former balloon factory to remove hundreds of containers of hazardous materials in Malvern, Ohio.

Excavated more than 5,000 tons of PCB-contaminated soil discovered by the city of Detroit during construction of the Joe Louis Greenway.

Cleaned up properties contaminated by a fire at a Newburgh, Indiana, manufacturing facility which spread caustic ash over a large part of the community.

Removed Muskegon Lake, Michigan, from the list of the most environmentally degraded areas in the Great Lakes.

Reached a settlement to resolve alleged lead-paint renovation violations in South Bend, Indiana.

Reached settlement for alleged violations of the Clean Air Act requiring company to reduce lead and particulate matter emissions.

Sailed more than 8,000 miles, sampled 382 sites and hosted hundreds of students and visitors during EPA research vessel Lake Guardian's 2025 survey of Great Lakes water quality.

Collaborated with the state of Ohio and numerous local partners to begin the long-anticipated process to remove Cuyahoga River's Gorge Dam.

Removed more than 2,100 tons of spilled asphalt from the Chicago Ship and Sanitary Canal.

Led emergency response at Smitty Supply explosion and fire in Louisiana deploying 464 EPA employees and contractors to conduct air monitoring and recover 7,622,181 gallons of oily waste and 3,769,668 gallons of CERCLA waste from the Tangipahoa River.

Signed final Clean Air Act Minor New Source Review permit for Texas GulfLink Deepwater Port, the first use of an offshore support vessel to house VOC vapor control technology.

Conducted oversight of the depressurization of four flanged tritium waste containers at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico.

Signed proposed approval of Oklahoma SIP Revisions for New Source Review permitting and general SIP updates, addressing 13 SIP submittals.

Provided expedited sample results for 61 indoor air samples for volatile organic compounds from 16 residential properties in the CCI Superfund site in Kansas.

Awarded task order contract that reduces mobilization time by approximately 280 days for the Superfund Removal and Remedial Program in Region 7.

Awarded $148,000 to the City of Cambridge, Nebraska, for rehabilitation of Cambridge's Wastewater Treatment Plant.

Collected fish tissue samples at four locations near Montrose, Missouri, to address potential concerns with the Montrose facility and fly ash storage.

Signed a final action to approve revisions to the Missouri SIP to resolve a discrepancy between federal and state requirements.

Signed a final action to approve revisions to the Kansas SIP to redesignate the Salina Area from nonattainment to attainment for the 2008 Lead (Pb) NAAQS.

Collected and analyzed bacterial samples at 48 sites on the Maquoketa and upper Iowa River watersheds in northeast Iowa.

Finalized agreement with liable parties for cleanup of a 15,000-ton pile of elemental sulfur in Peru, Kansas, resulting in site cleanup at no taxpayer cost.

Approved an aquifer exemption for the Lisbon Valley Mine Project in Utah to include underground recovery of copper, expanding current mining operations with less surface disturbance.

Signed North Dakota's Coal Combustion Residuals (CCR) final rule, allowing the state to permit CCR disposal in surface impoundments and landfills.

Signed a proposed rule approving a SIP revision for Montana, addressing regional haze and visibility requirements related to the 2015 ozone National Ambient Air Quality Standard.

Approved revisions to Montana's water quality standards in House Bill 664, maintaining narrative criteria to protect against harmful effects of nutrient pollution.

Signed a Memorandum of Agreement with the Blackfeet Tribe in Montana and Idaho to create NPDES permitting efficiencies for the Clean Water Act Section 401 Process.

Supported Colorado’s efforts in a chemical removal action at Otero County schools, with over 3,400 containers added to collection efforts.

Reached a settlement with Kennecott Utah Copper requiring the mining company to monitor wetlands, study groundwater contamination, and pay oversight costs at the Kennecott North Zone Superfund Site near Salt Lake City, Utah.

Hosted Proposed Plan public meeting in Billings, Montana, with record attendance, identifying EPA's Preferred Alternative for addressing contaminated indoor air detected in homes, schools, and commercial buildings in the downtown area.

Paved the way toward cleanup at the Northeast Church Rock site near Gallup, New Mexico, by concluding a consent decree to remove approximately one million cubic yards of uranium mine waste.

Completed removal of approximately 150,000 pounds of illegally stored fireworks, nitrous oxide gas, and hand sanitizer at a warehouse in Commerce, California.

Completed Dededo waste piles removal action in Guam, removing approximately 31,000 cubic yards of contaminated soil and installing new fencing to prevent future dumping.

Concluded an agreement with owners of a supermarket chain to remove multiple unregistered pesticides illegally sold throughout Arizona, California, and Nevada.

Completed four PFAS treatment systems to safeguard drinking water in southern California's Irvine Ranch and Orange County Water Districts to protect over 9,500 households from PFAS.

Began oversight of unprecedented lithium-ion battery removal from the Moss Landing, California, energy storage facility damaged in a January 2025 fire.

Completed transfer of almost one million tons of Maui wildfire debris to permanent disposal two months ahead of schedule, transitioning to the restoration phase.

Issued five orders to drinking water systems in Arizona, California, and Nevada for failing to complete lead service line inventories and customer notifications.

Completed remediation of 413,000 cubic yards of mine wastes and restoration of 17 acres Bunker Hill Superfund Site's Tamarack Complex project in northern Idaho and eastern Washington.

Completed the Gray's Meadow Remedial Action in Idaho restoring 695 acres of former agricultural land to clean wetland habitat.

Approved Alaska's Air Quality Plan for Fairbanks North Star Borough, providing cleaner air while saving Alaskans from costly provisions.

Issued Cooperative Agreements to advance cleanup of contaminated Alaska Native Corporation lands, with 296 sites remaining to be verified out of nearly 1,200.

Remobilized to the Cosmo Specialty Fibers site in Washington to conduct an expanded removal evaluation assessing risks to nearby fish-bearing waters from hundreds of thousands of gallons of chemicals remaining in over 47 above-ground storage tanks after mill closure.

Awarded the City of Seattle $3 million to help implement their South Park Drainage Improvements Project, that will manage stormwater, reduce flooding, and protect Seattle residents, property, and public infrastructure from contaminants like BETX, VOCs, and various metals.

Awarded a $965,000 Community Grant to the Town of Washtucna in Washington State to design and construct a new community well and pump station, bolstering the reliability of a safe drinking water supply for the community.

Approved Texas SIP for SO2 interstate transport requirements.

title: Cobalt, Corruption, and Childhood: Failures and Risks in the Global Supply Chain
description:
It also considers how China’s dominant position in the global cobalt supply chain and broader corporate practices further weaken protections for children’s environmental health.
This section examines the environmental consequences cobalt mining imposes on Congolese children, particularly those linked to informal mining and broader governance failures.
Recent U.S. and European initiatives aim to correct structural imbalances in the global cobalt trade.
Unless accompanied by parallel efforts to formalize ASM, combat corruption, and strengthen local enforcement, supply chain restructuring risks becoming a geopolitical strategy that marginalizes the communities most affected by extraction.
Cobalt from unregulated sites routinely enters the global supply chain, aided by falsified documentation, official collusion, and bribes paid to border officials.
text:
This article examines the severe environmental health risks facing children who work in cobalt mines in the DRC and analyzes the legal and institutional failures that enable these harms—focusing on the limitations of international law, gaps in domestic enforcement, and the narrowing scope of the primary U.S. antibribery statute governing corporate conduct abroad. It also considers how China’s dominant position in the global cobalt supply chain and broader corporate practices further weaken protections for children’s environmental health. Framed through the lens of environmental justice and equity, the article concludes with targeted legal and policy recommendations aimed at strengthening corporate accountability, promoting ethical sourcing, and safeguarding vulnerable populations in high-risk supply chains characterized by weak oversight, environmental harm, and labor exploitation.

Cobalt Mining Effects on Children

More than 70% of the world’s cobalt is mined in the DRC, with a significant share extracted in the southeastern provinces of Lualaba and Haut-Katanga. See From Cobalt to Cars: How China Exploits Child and Forced Labor in DR Congo: Hearing Before the Cong.-Exec. Comm’n on China, 118th Cong. (Nov. 14, 2023). These regions include the mining-intensive cities of Kolwezi and Lubumbashi, where cobalt extraction dominates the local economy. In this part of the country, children face daily exposure to hazardous substances—through direct labor in cobalt mines and environmental contamination in nearby communities. See Amnesty Int’l, This Is What We Die For: Human Rights Abuses in the Democratic Republic of the Congo Power the Global Trade in Cobalt 19–33 (2016). An estimated 35,000 to 40,000 children live or work near mining sites, many of them digging ore from narrow tunnels, hauling heavy sacks of raw cobalt, and handling minerals without gloves, masks, or access to clean water. See From Cobalt to Cars, supra. Thousands more suffer indirect exposure by inhaling cobalt-laden dust or drinking water from rivers and wells contaminated by mining runoff. See Karly Domb Sadof et al., The Hidden Costs of Cobalt Mining, Wash. Post, Feb. 28, 2018.

Despite mounting evidence from medical researchers, environmental scientists, and human rights organizations documenting cobalt’s toxic effects on human health, these conditions have persisted with little meaningful intervention. The environmental health crisis unfolding across the DRC’s mining regions is not an unforeseen consequence of rapid mineral extraction: It is the predictable outcome of weak legal enforcement, fragmented oversight, and the failure of both domestic and international systems to safeguard vulnerable communities. This section examines the environmental consequences cobalt mining imposes on Congolese children, particularly those linked to informal mining and broader governance failures.

The most acute human health risks arise in the context of artisanal and small-scale mining (ASM), that is, operations that rely on manual extraction with minimal mechanization and virtually no government oversight. See U.S. Dep’t of Labor, Forced Labor in Cobalt Mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo 2–5, 22, 27–30 (May 2023). Although many ASM sites are loosely organized by traders, intermediaries, or cooperative leaders, these operations often remain informal or illegal, operating outside the regulatory framework governing industrial mining and providing little to no protection for workers or nearby residents. Id. In the cobalt sector, ASM accounts for an estimated 15 to 30% of national production and supports thousands of families. See Dorothée Baumann-Pauly, Cobalt Mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo: Addressing Root Causes of Human Rights Abuses 3, 5 (N.Y.U. Stern Ctr. for Bus. & Hum. Rts. & Geneva Ctr. for Bus. & Hum. Rts., Feb. 2023). These sites, often dug by hand, lack reinforcement, ventilation, or safety protocols and frequently collapse.

As children dig, crush, sort, and wash cobalt ore, they inhale toxic dust and come into frequent contact with contaminated soil and water—exposures that typically occur without masks, gloves, or other basic personal protective equipment. See Amnesty Int’l, This Is What We Die For, supra, at 19–30. Prolonged inhalation of cobalt-mining dust can lead to hard metal lung disease and other respiratory ailments, while repeated interaction with polluted soil, dust, and water exposes children to uranium, lead, and other toxic metals that commonly occur alongside cobalt deposits and are released into the environment during ore extraction and processing. See Fleur Scheele et al., Cobalt Blues: Environmental Pollution and Human Rights Violations in Katanga’s Copper and Cobalt Mines 21–26 (Centre for Rsch. on Multinational Corp. 2016). Combined exposure to these metals can heighten toxic effects, increasing the overall health risks for those living and working in mining areas. See C. L. N. Banza et al., Sustainability of Artisanal Mining of Cobalt in DR Congo, 1 Nat. Sustainability 495, 498–99 (2018). Scientific studies in communities near artisanal cobalt mines have documented elevated concentrations of these metals in children’s blood and urine, with biomarkers indicating systemic toxicity, oxidative stress, and DNA damage. Id. Such health outcomes are not anomalies—they reflect widespread, predictable consequences of ASM’s unregulated nature and the government’s failure to implement health-protective regulation.

Beyond acute respiratory and toxicological symptoms, chronic exposure to cobalt and associated heavy metals poses serious long-term risks to children’s health in affected mining regions. See Connor W. Brown et al., Occupational, Environmental, and Toxicological Health Risks of Mining Metals for Lithium-Ion Batteries: A Narrative Review of the PubMed Database, 19 J. Occupational Med. & Toxicology 35, 37 (2024). Children are especially vulnerable due to higher absorption rates, immature detoxification systems, and frequent hand-to-mouth behaviors that increase exposure to mining pollutants. See RAID & AFREWATCH, Beneath the Green: A Critical Look at the Environmental and Human Costs of Industrial Cobalt Mining in DRC 40 (Mar. 2024). Compounding these dangers are malnutrition, unsanitary living conditions, and limited access to medical care. See Amnesty Int’l, This Is What We Die For, supra, at 23–24, 30–32. For many children, long hours in or near mining sites replace time in school, reinforcing cycles of poverty and ill health. Id. at 28–32.

Nowhere are these environmental health risks more visible than in Kolwezi, where artisanal sites operate just steps from homes, schools, and markets. In neighborhoods like Kasulo, families live amid open pits, metal-laden waste, and clouds of dust. See Todd C. Frankel, The Cobalt Pipeline: Tracing the Path from Deadly Hand-Dug Mines in Congo to Consumers’ Phones and Laptops, Wash. Post, Sept. 30, 2016. A 2018 study found that children living near these sites had urinary cobalt levels more than 10 times higher than those in non-mining areas, with elevated levels of uranium and manganese as well. See Banza et al., supra, at 498–99. Researchers found signs of toxic exposure even among children not directly engaged in mining, illustrating how environmental contamination affects entire communities, not just those working in the mines. Id. at 500–01. In Kolwezi, as in other mining communities, families face stark choices: expose their children to toxic environments in exchange for income or slip deeper into poverty. These conditions persist with little oversight—underscoring how the DRC’s cobalt economy externalizes its environmental and health costs onto its most vulnerable residents.

Cobalt Supply Chains and Global Accountability

The environmental harms facing Congolese mining communities are not simply by-products of weak enforcement—they are embedded in a transnational supply chain that obscures origin, fragments responsibility, and rewards opacity. Although the DRC produces most of the world’s cobalt, the path from mine to market is shaped by layers of intermediaries, refiners, and manufacturers whose geographic and legal distance from extraction sites renders accountability elusive. China is at the center of this structure, controlling the vast majority of cobalt refining capacity and holding significant stakes in the DRC’s most productive mines. This concentration of power enables downstream firms to source cobalt at scale while avoiding direct engagement with the conditions of its extraction, deepening the disconnect between environmental justice principles and global resource governance.

Chinese companies now own or control stakes in at least 15 of the 19 largest industrial cobalt operations in the DRC, including some of the country’s highest-output mines. See Patrick Anderson, Cobalt and Corruption: The Influence of Multinational Firms and Foreign States on the Democratic Republic of the Congo, 14 J. Glob. Bus. & Cmty. 1, 2, 7–9 (2023). Firms such as China Molybdenum, Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt, and Sinohydro have secured long-term access through joint ventures with state-owned Congolese companies and opaque acquisitions brokered over the past two decades. Id. at 7–9. These companies often indirectly rely on subcontractors and intermediaries to source cobalt, including material from artisanal mining sites. See Matthieu Bolay & Filipe Calvão, Labour, Incorporated: Dependent Contracting and Wageless Work in Africa’s “Responsible” Mines, 62 Cahiers d’Études Africaines, no. 245/246 (1/2), 2022, at 123, 134–36. Once extracted, most raw cobalt is exported to China for refining and processing. See Suleyman O. Altiparmak et al., Cornering the Market with Foreign Direct Investments: China’s Cobalt Politics, 7 Renewable & Sustainable Energy Transition, art. 100113, at 5–6 (2025). By 2024, Chinese refineries handled approximately 83% of global cobalt output—up from 65% in 2018—and the six largest refiners globally are all Chinese. See Jon Emont, How China Beat Out the U.S. to Become the Top Player in Rare-Earths Refining, Wall St. J., Mar. 24, 2025. From there, cobalt enters manufacturing chains that supply battery producers and end-users across North America, Europe, and Asia. See U.S. Energy Info. Admin., China Dominates Global Trade of Battery Minerals (May 21, 2025). This vertically integrated model consolidates China’s control over sourcing and processing while creating multiple degrees of separation between multinational buyers and extraction sites—particularly those reliant on artisanal or unregulated labor. The resulting structure generates an accountability gap that obscures the true human and environmental costs of the global cobalt trade.

This arrangement allows multinational firms to benefit from Congolese cobalt while remaining insulated from the conditions under which it is mined. Brands such as Apple, Tesla, Samsung, and General Motors remain heavily reliant on cobalt processed through predominantly Chinese-controlled channels, where sourcing practices are often unclear and weakly regulated. See RAID & CAJJ, The Road to Ruin? Electric Vehicles and Workers’ Rights Abuses at DR Congo’s Industrial Cobalt Mines 6, 14, 18–19, 25–28, 60, 65 (Nov. 2021). While these companies typically do not purchase directly from ASM sites, they profit from a procurement system in which cobalt extracted under hazardous and exploitative conditions is indistinguishably blended into global supply. See Siddharth Kara, Cobalt Red: How the Blood of the Congo Powers Our Lives (2023). In 2019, several Congolese families filed suit in Doe v. Apple Inc., alleging that Apple, Alphabet, Dell, Microsoft, and Tesla had “knowingly benefited” from forced child labor in cobalt mines operated by their suppliers. The complaint described children working underground for as little as two dollars a day, exposed to tunnel collapses and toxic dust without protective equipment. The suit was ultimately dismissed on procedural grounds, including lack of standing and difficulty establishing direct causation—highlighting the structural challenges of imposing liability on downstream firms. See Compl. ¶¶ 5–8, Doe v. Apple Inc., No. 1:19-cv-03737 (D.D.C. Dec. 16, 2019).

Many companies cite supplier audits, traceability initiatives, and voluntary certification schemes as evidence of ethical sourcing. Yet, these mechanisms often fail to detect or deter the flow of cobalt from unregulated ASM operations. Certification programs—such as the Responsible Minerals Assurance Process—rely heavily on self-reporting and limited third-party verification, methods ill-suited to fragmented, transnational supply chains. See Galit A. Sarfaty & Raphael Deberdt, Supply Chain Governance at a Distance, 49 Law & Soc. Inquiry 1036, 1046–53 (2024). In practice, corporate actors operate within systems where legal responsibility is diffused, while profits remain concentrated. Public commitments to responsible sourcing frequently coexist with procurement practices that externalize social and environmental risks onto those at the base of the supply chain. Id. at 1052–53.

Recent U.S. and European initiatives aim to correct structural imbalances in the global cobalt trade. The U.S. Department of State’s Minerals Security Partnership promotes secure and resilient supply chains by supporting investment in critical minerals projects in resource-rich nations and recently endorsed principles for high environmental, social, and governance (ESG) standards. Similarly, the European Union’s Critical Raw Materials Act introduces mechanisms to diversify sourcing and improve transparency. While these policies signal a shift toward greater market resilience, they remain in early stages and focus primarily on securing material access—not labor protections, environmental safeguards, or governance reforms in producer countries. Unless accompanied by parallel efforts to formalize ASM, combat corruption, and strengthen local enforcement, supply chain restructuring risks becoming a geopolitical strategy that marginalizes the communities most affected by extraction.

Global awareness of cobalt’s human costs is growing, and reform efforts are becoming more visible. But without robust legal accountability and investment in equitable governance at the source, the harms embedded in cobalt supply chains will continue to fall on Congolese mining communities, particularly children, even as global markets reap the rewards.

Legal and Regulatory Gaps in Cobalt Governance

Despite the severity of environmental and labor abuses in the DRC’s cobalt mining sector, international human rights law remains ill-equipped to address these harms. Key instruments, such as the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) and the International Labour Organization’s Convention No. 182 on the Worst Forms of Child Labour, establish standards but lack enforcement mechanisms. The CRC relies on mandatory periodic reporting rather than adjudicatory remedies. See U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child, Nov. 20, 1989, 1577 U.N.T.S. 3. Convention No. 182 depends on domestic implementation and provides no international complaints mechanism or private right of action for victims. Similarly, the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights are nonbinding and impose no legal obligations on companies. Advocacy efforts to develop a binding treaty on business and human rights or to codify “ecocide” under the Rome Statute have gained traction but remain politically stalled. See Joe Udell, Environmental Destruction and Human Rights Abuses in the Democratic Republic of the Congo: Examining the Epicenter of the Cobalt Mining Industry from an International Criminal Law Perspective, 32 Minn. J. Int’l L. 195, 198–200, 212–13, 215–16 (2023).

While international frameworks remain aspirational, the implementation of mining regulations in the DRC presents its own systemic failures. The 2018 Mining Code includes provisions to formalize ASM, protect workers, and establish designated artisanal mining zones (Zones d’Exploitation Artisanale, ZEAs), but enforcement remains sporadic and ineffective. Most artisanal miners continue to operate in unregulated conditions, as ZEAs either do not exist or lack meaningful oversight—leaving workers vulnerable to hazardous conditions, extortion, and violence. SAEMAPE, the agency tasked with supporting and monitoring artisanal mining, often lacks the resources to inspect sites or enforce safety protocols. See Emmanuel Umpula et al., Islands of Responsibility? Corporate Sourcing of Artisanal Cobalt in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Int’l Inst. for Env’t & Dev. 10–11, 18–19 (2021).

Corruption and institutional weakness further undermine oversight. In 2019, the government created two new institutions: the Entreprise Générale du Cobalt (EGC), tasked with formalizing artisanal cobalt purchasing, and the Autorité de Régulation et de Contrôle des Marchés des Substances Minérales Stratégiques (ARECOMS), charged with overseeing strategic mineral exports. Both were designed to improve traceability and curb illicit trade. Nevertheless, oversight remains weak despite these mandates. EGC has failed to stem illegal mining or smuggling, while ARECOMS continues to face operational challenges due to limited capacity and persistent corruption. See Aymeric Vincenot, DR Congo Bets on Cobalt Export Freeze to Halt Price Tumble, Agence France-Presse (Mar. 9, 2025). A 2025 study on environmental crime and mineral governance found that informal mining in the DRC remains largely beyond government control. See Zeynab Malakouti & Mohammad Hazrati, Interconnected Challenges: Examining the Nexus of Environmental Crime and Money Laundering in the Context of Energy Transition, 8 J. Econ. Criminol., art. 100151, at 4 (2025). Cobalt from unregulated sites routinely enters the global supply chain, aided by falsified documentation, official collusion, and bribes paid to border officials. See Henry Lazenby, Middlemen Siphon Billions from War-Ravaged DRC’s Cobalt, Coltan Trade, Mining.com (Feb. 10, 2025). According to a 2024 ENACT Observer report, the DRC loses nearly $1 billion annually to smuggling into Rwanda alone. See Oluwole Ojewale, Illegal Cobalt Mining Taints Transition to Green Technology, ENACT Observer (May 27, 2024). These failures not only erode the rule of law but also allow multinationals to source Congolese cobalt with little assurance that it was mined ethically or legally.

As domestic enforcement falters, transnational legal tools have been used to pursue corporate accountability. Chief among them is the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), which prohibits bribing foreign officials for business advantage. In 2022, Glencore International AG, a multinational mining and commodities trading company, pleaded guilty to bribing Congolese officials in exchange for access to cobalt and copper concessions. See Press Release, U.S. Dep’t of Just., Glencore Entered Guilty Pleas to Foreign Bribery and Market Manipulation Schemes (May 24, 2022). Yet, the case focused narrowly on financial misconduct and failed to address the broader labor and environmental abuses linked to Glencore’s operations. This narrow prosecutorial focus on bribery, rather than the broader supply chain abuses, reflects a deeper limitation in transnational enforcement: While bribery can trigger prosecution, systemic harms embedded in global supply chains often escape legal scrutiny. See Udell, supra, at 229–30.

Recent enforcement trends have further narrowed the reach of the FCPA. While early applications of the statute targeted systemic corporate misconduct, more recent cases have focused on individual executive culpability, often addressing discrete acts of bribery rather than broader patterns of abuse in global operations. See Veronica A. Guerrero et al., FCPA Enforcement: Back with a Twist? DOJ Issues New FCPA Guidelines Following Trump Executive Order, Arnold & Porter (June 11, 2025). This shift was previewed in February 2025, when an executive order directed the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) to pause new FCPA enforcement actions pending a policy review. See Exec. Order 14,209, Pausing Foreign Corrupt Practices Act Enforcement to Further American Economic and National Security, 90 Fed. Reg. 9587, 9588 (Feb. 14, 2025). Citing concerns about economic competitiveness and supply chain security, the directive raised alarm among anticorruption advocates who feared it signaled a broader retreat from corporate accountability abroad. Although the pause was lifted in June 2025, new DOJ guidance narrowed enforcement priorities to cases implicating U.S. strategic interests (such as critical minerals and national security), while deemphasizing broader corporate misconduct. See Memorandum from U.S. Dep’t of Just., Guidelines for Investigations and Enforcement of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (June 9, 2025). This change in focus has diminished the FCPA’s deterrent power, particularly in sectors like cobalt mining, where harms arise not from isolated acts of bribery but from structural conditions of environmental degradation, forced labor, and unclear supply chains.

In the absence of binding legal mandates, corporations have turned to voluntary initiatives to demonstrate ethical compliance. Programs such as the Cobalt Industry Responsible Assessment Framework and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s Due Diligence Guidance promote supply chain accountability but rely primarily on company self-reporting, with limited independent oversight or enforcement. Membership or participation is typically not revoked for noncompliance unless the failure is egregious or publicly exposed, leaving implementation effectively self-managed. These frameworks often prioritize reputational risk management over systemic reform, enabling companies to project a façade of ethical sourcing while distancing themselves from labor and environmental conditions at the extraction stage. See Umpula et al., supra, at 4. Many shift the burden of compliance onto local suppliers or third-party auditors, creating fragmented oversight with limited transparency. See Filipe Calvão et al., Cobalt Mining and the Corporate Outsourcing of Responsibility in the Democratic Republic of Congo, 8 Extractive Indus. & Soc’y, no. 4, 2021, art. 100884, at 8–9. In practice, this outsourcing of responsibility has enabled cobalt from hazardous and unregulated artisanal sites to enter global markets under the veneer of due diligence. Id. at 5–6, 8–9.

These layered failures—across international law, domestic governance, transnational enforcement, and corporate policy—create a global accountability vacuum where human rights and environmental harms persist unchecked. International legal instruments remain nonbinding or aspirational; domestic regulators in the DRC struggle with corruption, weak capacity, and institutional underperformance; and transnational tools like the FCPA are narrowly applied or temporarily paused. At the same time, voluntary corporate frameworks often allow companies to claim compliance even though oversight of upstream labor and environmental conditions at cobalt mining sites remains weak. See Amnesty Int’l, Time to Recharge: Corporate Action and Inaction to Tackle Abuses in the Cobalt Supply Chain 5–6, 8–9, 75 (2017). Absent mechanisms that align legal authority with corporate behavior, the inequities of the DRC’s cobalt economy will continue to fall on those least empowered to resist them.

Toward Accountability and Reform

Addressing the environmental health crisis linked to cobalt mining in the DRC requires more than market diversification or voluntary oversight. Legal and policy reforms must put the rights and health of affected communities at the center while closing the accountability gaps that enable global supply chains to profit from harm. The following measures, grounded in environmental justice and regulatory equity, offer a path forward.

First, domestic enforcement in the DRC must be strengthened through sustained investment in institutions tasked with overseeing artisanal mining. Agencies such as SAEMAPE and ARECOMS need stable funding, technical capacity, and operational independence to monitor mine sites, enforce safety standards, and trace mineral flows. The formalization of ASM—long promised but rarely realized—should be treated not as a bureaucratic benchmark, but as a human rights imperative. International donors and development banks can support these efforts by conditioning infrastructure and mineral-sector financing on transparent enforcement benchmarks and anticorruption safeguards.

Second, the United States should restore and expand the substantive reach of the FCPA. Future enforcement should move beyond transactional bribery to address broader patterns of misconduct, including environmental harm, labor exploitation, and corruption embedded in transnational supply chains. Given the extraterritorial nature of cobalt sourcing and mineral trade, U.S. efforts should be coordinated with complementary frameworks such as the UK Bribery Act and emerging European corporate accountability legislation.

Third, governments in cobalt-importing countries should replace voluntary sourcing frameworks with mandatory due diligence requirements. Recent EU legislation requiring companies to assess and address human rights and environmental risks across their supply chains provides a model. In the United States, disclosure-based laws—such as the Dodd-Frank conflict minerals provision—could be expanded to include cobalt, with specific attention to child labor, toxic exposure, and traceability gaps. Companies that fail to conduct meaningful risk assessments, or that knowingly source from unregulated artisanal mining sites, should face enforceable legal consequences.

Fourth, affected communities must have a voice in monitoring and remedy efforts. Civil society organizations and community-based observers in cobalt mining regions should be funded and empowered to report abuses, monitor site conditions, and provide ground-level feedback on whether sourcing practices reflect local realities. Community participation in oversight initiatives and grievance processes is essential to establish legitimacy and build trust. To root these systems in local perspectives, international minerals partnerships should require Congolese civil society representation in governance structures and ensure community members have access to complaint mechanisms that yield meaningful outcomes.

Finally, supply chain resilience must be redefined to include environmental health and human rights. Policies promoting critical mineral security—whether through domestic production, stockpiling, or foreign investment—also should embed standards for safe working conditions, pollution prevention, and child protection. Public and private procurement frameworks should incorporate environmental justice criteria into supplier eligibility, rewarding firms that demonstrate ethical sourcing at the ground level.

As the world accelerates toward a clean energy future, the urgency of securing critical minerals must not eclipse the rights of those most harmed by their extraction. In cobalt-rich regions of the DRC, children continue to suffer toxic and exploitative consequences of a supply chain built for efficiency, not accountability. These harms are not inevitable. They stem from legal failures, weak enforcement, and corporate structures that obscure responsibility. Ensuring that environmental progress does not come at the cost of human dignity requires more than due diligence checklists or corporate pledges of ethical sourcing. It demands enforceable laws, equitable oversight, and sustained international engagement with the communities that power the transition. Only by closing legal and accountability gaps can the energy transition fulfill its promise of equity as well as sustainability.

title: The Back Page: Policy and Politics of the Abundance Movement - American Bar Association
description:
While both political parties are taken to task in the book, blue states and Democratic policies are a focus from a left-of-center perspective.
One Klein and Thompson criticism is that environmental and similar laws, while necessary, have become focused on process over outcome.
Klein and Thompson argue that Democratic elected officials should shift toward supporting pro-growth and development policies, particularly in the energy sector.
Notably, not all Democratic elected officials support the abundance movement, and there is certainly NGO and other opposition.
The differing opinions on the abundance movement preview potential political fault lines within the Democratic Party, which may have electoral but also practical implications on public policy priorities relevant to Section members and our clients.
text:
Abundance, the book by Ezra Klein and Derek Thompson, is a critical assessment of federal and state policies that—they argue—have resulted in the U.S.’s inability to think big to tackle today’s public policy challenges. While both political parties are taken to task in the book, blue states and Democratic policies are a focus from a left-of-center perspective. Whether it is the inability to build high-speed rail in the country, the failure to develop energy generation and transmission projects to meet surging energy demand and mitigate climate change, or being incapable of constructing new housing at a pace to tackle cost of living concerns, the status quo is not working. Further, Klein and Thompson argue that these failings have political implications, with Democratic elected officials losing voters’ trust because of governing failures in blue cities and states. The issues highlighted in the book are at the core of the work of many Section members, and the expectation is that abundance-related policy and politics will remain center stage in the near term.

One Klein and Thompson criticism is that environmental and similar laws, while necessary, have become focused on process over outcome. An abundance agenda seeks to reform government (e.g., loosening zoning laws, simplifying environmental permitting, speeding up infrastructure projects) to focus on building and innovation as central to liberal governance. This approach requires honesty that there are trade-offs involved. For example, advancing infrastructure projects more quickly may result in greater localized environmental impacts, or NIMBY opposition to housing density may need to take a back seat to the greater public benefit of more and cheaper homes in blue states.

Climate change is an example of our inability to tackle big problems. There is simply no scenario where the U.S. both can meet surging energy demand due to data centers and emerging AI technologies and mitigate climate change without a historic and herculean effort to build the necessary energy infrastructure. The Biden administration prioritized climate change unlike any prior administration. Congress passed historic legislation providing hundreds of billions of dollars to build the necessary infrastructure. However, the federal government and blue state approach to environmental reviews and permitting for the necessary infrastructure did not align with those policy goals and the claimed urgency. The U.S. must build more and at unprecedented speed, scale, and scope. Klein and Thompson argue that Democratic elected officials should shift toward supporting pro-growth and development policies, particularly in the energy sector. Politicians who want to enact ambitious government programs need to show voters they are capable of implementing such programs.

Nowhere is this policy and political shift more apparent than in California, where Governor Newsom and other elected officials have adopted abundance-focused policies. When signing legislation to limit the applicability of the California Environmental Quality Act to housing development, Governor Newsom explained, “We’re urgently embracing an abundance agenda by tearing down the barriers that have delayed new affordable housing and infrastructure for decades.” Newsom also signed legislation lifting the moratorium on carbon dioxide pipelines, which are critical for carbon capture and sequestration projects, and signed legislation to authorize the development of additional oil and gas resources in the state. Notably, not all Democratic elected officials support the abundance movement, and there is certainly NGO and other opposition.

The differing opinions on the abundance movement preview potential political fault lines within the Democratic Party, which may have electoral but also practical implications on public policy priorities relevant to Section members and our clients. The lasting power of the abundance movement may impact the ability to push necessary infrastructure development, thereby restoring public faith in the role of government to provide a foundation for the county to tackle big problems.

title: PFAS and the Future of Environmental Justice Regulation - American Bar Association
description:
Consequently, regulation of PFAS contamination of drinking water has become a hot topic in environmental regulation broadly and environmental justice specifically.
While the Trump EPA does not explicitly reject the concept of environmental justice, broader trends at the agency indicate that environmental justice will not be a priority.
The Future of Environmental Justice in Safe Drinking Water The new regulatory standards for PFAS contamination of drinking water arrive at a tumultuous moment for regulatory law.
Finally, integrating a more granular approach to environmental justice in drinking water contamination law necessitates a more localized approach.
Despite the Trump administration’s disinterest in environmental justice at the federal level, its decentralized approach to this issue may permit the persistence of environmental justice efforts at other geographic levels.
text:
Exposure to PFAS contamination is associated with a wide variety of detrimental health effects. The immune system and thyroid function can be compromised, and liver and kidney diseases are more likely, as are reproductive and infant development issues. S.E. Fenton et al., Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substance Toxicity and Human Health Review: Current State of Knowledge and Strategies for Informing Future Research, 40 Env’t Toxicology & Chemistry 606 (2021). Certain types of cancer are also more prevalent with PFAS exposure. While research on these effects is ongoing, the present understanding of these effects is that they are chronic, except in cases of extremely high exposure. U.S. Env’t Prot. Agency (EPA), Our Current Understanding of the Human Health and Environmental Risks of PFAS (2024). Higher exposures in adults are generally associated with occupational risks, such as industrial workers or firefighters who produce and use PFAS products consistently. The risk of high-level exposure in children presents a different, more concerning issue.

Because children are smaller than adults, the relative concentration of contaminants to body size presents a more significant health risk. Further, young children are more likely to be exposed to PFAS-derived products while crawling and putting objects in their mouths. These exposures can lead to developmental effects or delays, variation in bone growth, puberty changes, and even behavioral issues. These effects may be subtle and widespread across populations who are exposed, even at relatively low levels, to PFAS in their environment and drinking water. Jennifer L. Ames, Vanshika Sharma & Kristen Lyall, Effects of Early-life PFAS Exposure on Child Neurodevelopment: A Review of the Evidence and Research Gaps, 12 Current Env’t Health Rep. 9 (2025). While we are still working to assess the social correlates of PFAS contamination, we would expect them to correlate to patterns of race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status, as do other categories of drinking water contamination. David Switzer & Manuel P. Teodoro, Class, Race, Ethnicity, and Justice in Safe Drinking Water Compliance, 99 Soc. Sci. Q. 524 (2018). Consequently, regulation of PFAS contamination of drinking water has become a hot topic in environmental regulation broadly and environmental justice specifically.

How Is PFAS Contamination in Drinking Water Regulated?

Local drinking water utilities are governed by the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA), 42 U.S.C. §§ 300f et seq. (2018). Under the SDWA, utilities are required to regularly collect samples, which are sent to a certified laboratory and tested for a variety of contaminants. Violations come in a variety of forms, but health violations are the most salient and include sample contaminant levels in excess of regulatory standards and failures to comply with treatment technique standards. The EPA regularly releases data on these violations and water utilities more generally, allowing social scientists to test for correlations between the likelihood of violations and a variety of potential causes, ranging from utility characteristics to the racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic composition of the populations those utilities serve. David M. Konisky & Manuel P. Teodoro, When Governments Regulate Governments, 60 Am. J. Pol. Sci. 559 (2016). This analysis of social and demographic correlations is an effort to pursue environmental justice and address the unequal distribution of violations in areas that are poor and disproportionately made up of members of disadvantaged communities. Switzer & Teodoro, supra. Nearly 100 contaminants are currently regulated under the SDWA, with more being added all the time. PFAS constitute the most recent set of additions to the list.

In 2024, EPA established regulatory limits for PFAS contamination in drinking water under the SDWA. See PFAS National Primary Drinking Water Regulation, 89 Fed. Reg. 32,532 (Apr. 26, 2024). The rule sets limits for six categories of PFAS compounds: four parts per trillion (ppt) for PFOA and PFOS, and four more categories (perfluorononanoic acid (PFNA), perfluorohexane sulfonate (PFHxS), perfluorobutane sulfonic acid (PFBS), and hexafluoropropylene oxide dimer acid (HFPO-DA, or GenX)) individually as well as aggregated in the form of an aggregated Hazard Index, the regulatory limit for which is set to 1.0. At present, these levels are remarkably aggressive in comparison to PFAS regulations globally. This decision has faced criticism from both scientists, who question their grounding in toxicology and epidemiology, J.A. Cotruvo, S.B. Goldhaber & A.J.B. Cohen, EPA’s Unprecedented Interim Drinking Water Health Advisories for PFOA and PFOS, 61 Groundwater 301 (2023), and industry groups, who cite high costs as a concern. A.L. Ling, Estimated Scale of Costs to Remove PFAS from the Environment at Current Emission Rates, 918 Sci. Total Env’t 170647 (2024).

This rule was promulgated under the Biden administration, and the administration’s commentary on the topic makes clear that environmental justice is to be a primary factor in implementation. EPA, Biden-Harris Administration Finalizes First-Ever National Drinking Water Standard to Protect 100M People from PFAS Pollution (2024). The Trump administration claimed credit for the rule (noting its origins in a 2019 initiative) and asserted its continued enforcement. While the Trump EPA does not explicitly reject the concept of environmental justice, broader trends at the agency indicate that environmental justice will not be a priority. EPA, EPA Announces It Will Keep Maximum Contaminant Levels for PFOA, PFOS (May 14, 2025). Instead, the Trump administration frames PFAS regulation in terms of small, rural communities, suggesting that these communities will require additional time to comply. This approach is in tension with the data on PFAS, which indicates that contamination is not as likely in less dense communities.

These regulations are designed to be gradually phased in, not taking full effect until 2029. However, testing for PFAS contamination of drinking water is already underway, and EPA has released the resultant data as part of the Fifth Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule dataset, allowing analysis of PFAS contamination across a large set of drinking water utilities, as well as its correlation to social and demographic factors. EPA, Fifth Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule Data Finder (2024). As such, we can examine this issue quantitatively through an environmental justice lens to assess the racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic correlates of PFAS contamination in drinking water.

Where and When Is PFAS Contamination Likely?

Environmental justice work on previously regulated contaminants under the SDWA has tended to treat all contaminants as basically identical, lumping them in together and looking at the patterns of race and ethnicity in SDWA violations in the aggregate. Switzer & Teodoro, supra. Our analysis of the new data on PFAS levels above the regulatory standard forces us to reconsider that picture. Michael A. Powell, David Switzer, & Manuel P. Teodoro, Disaggregating Disparities: Divergent Contamination in a Diverse Country, in Safe Drinking Water Act: The Next Fifty Years (Palgrave Macmillan, forthcoming). While the data on the new PFAS “Hazard Index” are too sparse for statistical analysis at this stage, we were able to analyze PFOS and PFOA contamination individually, and we found that the picture is substantially more complicated.

Our traditional understanding of the environmental justice of drinking water contamination—supported by aggregated statistical analysis—would suggest that the probability of contamination correlates positively with the percentage of a water system’s service population that is Black and/or Hispanic. Id. However, while the presence of PFOA and PFOS in drinking water is indeed positively correlated with the percent of the population served that is Black, PFOA is negatively correlated with the percent that is Hispanic. PFOS shows no significant correlation to Hispanic population. In short, PFAS is a problem primarily for Black communities, but not Hispanic ones, a fact that would not be apparent if they were aggregated with other violations of SDWA standards. Indeed, when we look specifically at nitrate contamination—usually attributable to agricultural runoff in rural areas—we find that the opposite pattern holds, and contamination is likelier for Hispanic than Black communities.

The relationship between PFAS contamination and community demographics is similarly complex. While SDWA violations in aggregate are likelier in poorer areas, the probability of PFOA contamination increases with increasing median household income and decreases as economic inequality widens—that is, PFOA contamination is most likely in wealthy communities. PFOS contamination is likeliest in very densely populated communities; however, aggregated SDWA violations are less likely in denser communities, but more likely in municipalities that serve a larger population in total (controlling for density).

Examining the characteristics of water systems likely to be contaminated with PFAS in excess of the regulatory standard hones our geography further. PFAS contamination is likeliest in older systems, possibly due to the simple fact that the stability of PFAS in the environment means that it is likeliest where it has had an opportunity to accumulate over time, and newer systems are most likely to be built in newly established communities.

In sum, PFAS contamination is disproportionately a problem for communities that are wealthy, long-established, and densely populated, with a history of heavy industry, with populations that are more Black but less Hispanic. This is in contrast not only with the pattern of SDWA violations more broadly—which are likeliest in communities that are both Black and Hispanic, with low income levels and large populations—and other categories of contaminant. Coliform, a prototypical bacterial contaminant with acute effects that lead to immediate endangerment of children, is correlated almost exclusively with population density; nitrate, which also can cause acute health issues that are particularly dangerous for infants, is likeliest in places with relatively high median income but an inequitable economic distribution. Both contaminants were regulated under the SDWA long before PFAS standards were implemented, and they remain a serious problem in many American communities.

More significantly, exposure to these “traditional” SDWA contaminants presents an emergent health threat, particularly to infants and children. The potential health effects of PFAS contamination are substantial, but they present a chronic rather than acute threat to human health, even in children, except in cases where exposure is very high. We might be tempted, in response to recent coverage of PFAS contamination and, perhaps, in search of precedent, to focus more of our energy on litigation arising from the new PFAS standards. We should take care in pursuing that impulse: While drinking water enforcement and litigation are not necessarily a zero-sum game across nearly 100 SDWA-governed contaminants, an excessive focus on PFAS may lead us to underrepresent the needs of communities whose children are in imminent danger from water tainted by more traditional contaminants that are currently less in the limelight.

As legal professionals, we also should be cognizant of the makeup of the communities we represent. Though PFAS is a significant public health issue that disproportionately impacts the Black community, it is also likeliest in communities that have the financial resources to address the issue. A disproportionate focus on PFAS contamination is, in effect, steering resources desperately needed by poor, rural communities to relatively wealthy, urban communities that likely have the ability to mitigate contamination despite a concentration of a historically disadvantaged population group, mirroring the competing frames of the PFAS rule under the Biden and Trump administrations. While the detrimental effects of PFAS on child development are significant and meaningful, a failure to address acute nitrate contamination may lead to death or permanent disability. Further, because PFAS contamination is less likely in Hispanic communities, focusing on it to the exclusion of other, less headline-grabbing contaminants may disadvantage that historically excluded group, even as Black populations benefit. While a response to the new regulations is natural, and even reasonable, we must take care not to overreact in response to novelty.

The Future of Environmental Justice in Safe Drinking Water

The new regulatory standards for PFAS contamination of drinking water arrive at a tumultuous moment for regulatory law. The recent decision in Loper Bright v. Raimondo, 603 U.S. 369 (2024), presages a foundational change to environmental governance broadly and environmental justice in drinking water specifically. Loper Bright abolished the Chevron doctrine, which required courts to give broad deference to the expertise of regulators in the implementation of legislation, in favor of the level of deference granted in Skidmore v. Swift & Co., 323 U.S. 134 (1944). Under Skidmore, courts are given primacy in the interpretation of legislative ambiguity, relegating regulators to a secondary role. In effect, this reversion transfers considerable power from the bureaucracy to courts. Putting aside assessment of that decision, it has substantial ramifications for any area of regulation defined by a high level of technical expertise. While we should presume the judiciary possesses considerable technical expertise in the legal arena, those of us who attended law school know that little to no time was spent on the particulars and mechanics of various chemical compounds, to say nothing of that chemistry’s effects on complex ecological systems or human toxicology. Continuing to work in these highly technical areas will require a reallocation of time and expertise for practicing attorneys.

In short, those of us who practice law relating to drinking water contamination should work to develop a deeper level of technical knowledge and to communicate the complex realities of environmental justice to judges who may now be forced to grapple with a host of highly technical regulatory areas. Winning strategies for litigation going forward will require attorneys to be adept at not only understanding the legal ramifications, but also the underlying scientific (and social scientific) reasoning governing those decisions. More importantly, we must develop the ability to communicate these highly technical concepts clearly and concisely. Understanding and communicating the differing patterns of various SDWA contaminants in use, health implications, and social correlations will be paramount, particularly in the early stages of the post–Loper Bright world. Until courts develop their own highly expert bureaucracy, it will be incumbent on us to distill the vast complexities of social and scientific interactions in drinking water regulation to a form compelling and usable by the judiciary. These complexities will have lasting public health implications for communities of color and, in particular, children of color.

Those of us interested in environmental justice also must take on a new burden in understanding the social and political ramifications of safe drinking water regulation and litigation. We must move beyond the impulse to treat Black, Hispanic, and low-income voters as broadly aligned and aggregated and engage with the more complicated reality of difficult trade-offs between disadvantaged communities. See, e.g., Hakeem Jefferson, The Curious Case of Black “Conservatives”: Assessing the Validity of the Liberal-Conservative Scale Among Black Americans, 88 Pub. Op. Q. 909 (2024); Eileen Díaz McConnell & Daniela A. Carreon, “It’s Not About Numbers, It’s About Power”: How Latino Young Adults Imagine the Ethnic and Racial Demographic Future of the United States, Am. Behav. Sci. (2024). Not only will understanding these societal linkages be vital to winning court cases, but they also must inform the practice of environmental justice law itself. If we are to continue to be on the front lines of the environmental justice struggle and continue to harness our legal skills to protect children from environmental degradation and contamination, we need to remain cognizant of the distributive effects of the allocation of our time and effort, particularly in the pro bono and public service arenas that are focused primarily on aiding underrepresented groups and individuals otherwise without the resources to retain legal counsel. Our ability to direct resources to where they are most needed gets at our most foundational obligation to professional ethics.

Failing to do so not only has ethical ramifications, but also political ramifications. The excessive aggregation of environmental justice analysis may have feedback effects that reinforce polarized, reactionary politics. The perceived redistribution of societal benefits away from rural areas in favor of urban populations has created significant political division over the last several years. Katherine J. Cramer, The Politics of Resentment: Rural Consciousness in Wisconsin and the Rise of Scott Walker (Univ. of Chi. Press 2016). Further, amalgamating racial and ethnic groups despite differing patterns in the distribution of drinking water contamination is likely to breed resentment in those communities, further fracturing the political landscape. Ivelisse Cuevas-Molina, White Racial Identity, Racial Attitudes, and Latino Partisanship, 8 J. Race, Ethnicity & Pol. 469 (2023). The effect of policy on social identity is profound, particularly for children and in interaction with other categories associated with social disadvantage. Mary Elizabeth Collins & Michelle Mead, Social Constructions of Children and Youth: Beyond Dependents and Deviants, 50 J. Soc. Pol’y 493 (2021). Failing to understand and address these patterns risks the further degradation of decades of imperfect but important environmental justice advocacy and litigation.

Finally, integrating a more granular approach to environmental justice in drinking water contamination law necessitates a more localized approach. Because of the variety of patterns across the numerous types of water contaminants governed under the SDWA, effective management of contaminant issues will be most effective at a local level where mitigation can be carefully and specifically targeted. The political landscape necessitates a similar approach to advocacy; under the current Congress, presidential administration, and Supreme Court, expanding the capabilities of regulatory agencies at the federal level is unlikely to succeed, particularly where the justification is grounded in environmental justice concerns. However, because of the SDWA’s highly delegated structure, there remains considerable opportunity to engage with these issues at the state and local levels. The current administration even has signaled a willingness to permit this type of engagement, emphasizing flexibility for water systems in rural communities in complying with the new PFAS standards. EPA, EPA Announces It Will Keep Maximum Contaminant Levels for PFOA, PFOS (2025). Despite the Trump administration’s disinterest in environmental justice at the federal level, its decentralized approach to this issue may permit the persistence of environmental justice efforts at other geographic levels. Focusing on not only advocacy but also negotiation and litigation at the state and local levels is the right approach to addressing the disparate patterns of contamination.

Scaling Up State and Local Mitigation Efforts

By focusing on smaller geographic scales for enforcement, we complicate the process of achieving safer drinking water at the national scale. However, doing so is not only the correct approach to tackling PFAS contamination in drinking water, but also offers the opportunity to work upward. State and local mitigation efforts offer useful test cases that may be scaled upward, particularly in states like California, Texas, or Pennsylvania, which possess large, diverse populations and a variety of land uses. Focusing on these potentially scalable laboratories of regulation is useful for not only testing effectiveness but also scalability, maximizing the likelihood that the approaches transmit both upward—to federal policy—and outward to other states. Local, granular approaches to solving drinking water contamination are the way forward—for attorneys, for communities, and for our children.
